The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 17th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.

p.span: The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 13 September 2023 and 18 October 2023.

span.span: 1. The committee resolved to present the following three petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 11291 petitioners—regarding a moratorium on offshore wind turbine developments off the Illawarra coastline (EN5444)
From 641 petitioners—regarding access to treatment for patients on opioid agonist medications (PN0571)
From 150 petitioners—requesting that residency or a visa extension be granted for Mr Peter Hodgson (PN0572)

span.span: ministerial responses to petitions were received:
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 18 October 2023

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following three petitions:
Renewable Energy

This petition is opposing the Climate Change and Energy Minister Chris Bowen's plans to approve wind turbines being built off the Illawarra coastline. This will allow 105+ offshore wind turbines, each 260m+ in height plus 3 off-shore substations to be located 10km off the Northern Illawarra coastline and 30km off the Kiama coastline. These will be visible during the day and at night their red flashing aviation lights and white marine navigation lights will destroy the visual amenity. Research shows that underwater noise from offshore developments reduces the survival rate of marine animals and birdlife due to their impact on navigation, mating, marine ecosystems and migration pathways. The proposed REZ at 10km offshore will intrude into the zone protected <15km offshore for whale migration! The noise during construction will be detectable to residents 100km away. Research shows offshore turbines built within view of the coastline up to 42km offshore, negatively impacts property values and tourism. The Illawarra coast is a major tourism destination. Exclusion zones around the turbines will restrict recreational fishers and divers across an area which covers 1,461km² of pristine ocean! Finally, each of the 315 turbine blades are 170m long, or the length of soccer field, and are not recyclable. This means they will only add to landfill as they are doing now overseas.
We therefore ask the House to stop wind turbine power plants being built off the Illawarra coastline. If the community does not want this project, we ask the House to stop it.
from 11,291 citizens (Petition No. EN5444)
Opioid Dependence

Changes to funding for opioid treatment in Australia, and a move to prioritise pharmacy-based treatment, are disastrous measures that will lead to the closure of all private opioid treatment services in NSW, resulting in the loss of thousands of crucial treatment places, increased waiting times for public services, and co-payments for GP consultations. Additionally, public Clinics, which previously provided free treatment, may require patients to pay co-pays for their medications. The existing system allows patients to choose a doctor, medication, and dosing point that suits their health needs—the loss of private treatment services due to lack of funding and support will have a significant, negative impact on patient choice, worsen patient access to treatment, and will lead to serious drug-related issues in our local communities as a result of increased criminality and illicit supply of dangerous, unregulated drugs. Similarly, increasing fees at public Clinics will significantly disadvantage some of our most vulnerable patients, and create further barriers to ongoing treatment for their issues.

We therefore ask the House to re-examine the changes to Opioid Dependence Treatment, to provide a funding stream for private Clinics and other private services that will allow them to stay open to provide care to their patients, and to provide funding to cover the costs of patient admission and treatment in the Commonwealth-subsidised public treatment services. This will allow private services providing Opiate Agonist Treatment to remain viable, and therefore allow for greater patient choice and freedom of treatment over the proposed pharmacy dispensing model.
from 641 citizens (Petition No. PN0571)
Hodgson, Mr Peter

Mr Peter Hodgson came to Australia to support his son following a one punch attack in Perth requiring the need for round the clock care. He has been financing the medical treatment and spending 60 hours a week assisting his son Danny with rehabilitation. We are asking the Minister to show compassion and grant Mr Peter Hodgson permanent residency or at least extending his temporary Visa due to expire October 19th. The stress this is causing to Danny and his father should be taken into consideration.

We therefore ask the House to support this father to remain in Australia to assist his son who through no fault of his own is a survivor of a one punch attack that has left him needing round the clock the support due to seizures and the need for ongoing rehabilitation. His attacker was jailed but no financial compensation was paid to the victim in this case Danny. We believe the majority of Australians would expect our government to show compassion and grant the application.
from 150 citizens (Petition No. PN0572)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 67 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Mental Health
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN4157 on the inclusion of forensic psychological interventions under Medicare.

The Australian Government is aware of the challenges people are experiencing in accessing affordable and high-quality mental health care. The Government also understands that people who have contact with the justice system can be disproportionately impacted by the social determinants of mental ill-health, such as homelessness and unemployment, and often have complex mental health needs.

The Government funds a range of mental health services including Medicare-subsidised services and other free or low-cost services for people with or at risk of mental illness. These include regional services commissioned by Australia's 31 Primary Health Networks, a national network of Head to Health Adult Mental Health Centres, and headspace which provides support to young people aged 12-25 years.
Most Medicare-subsidised mental health services are currently delivered through the

Better Access to Psychiatrists, Psychologists and General Practitioners through the Medicare Benefits Schedule initiative (Better Access). A recent evaluation of Better Access found that while people able to access treatment experienced positive outcomes, many people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, regional, rural and remote areas as well as aged care residents were missing out on treatment.

To address this, the Government will consider solutions not only to improve access to Medicare subsidised services, but also to a range of services across the mental health system. The Government is committed to working with both health professionals and those seeking treatment to ensure people have access to mental health care when and where they need it.

Through the 2023-24 Budget, the Government is investing $586.9 million in the mental health and suicide prevention system. This investment will lay the groundwork to make real, structural changes in response to the Better Access evaluation. It includes $91.3 million to address critical shortages in the psychology workforce and $17.8 million to upskill the broader health workforce in mental health. Improving the availability of the workforce will help ensure there is equity in service delivery, enabling longer-term reform.

In relation to expanding Medicare for other types of services, the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) is an independent body established to provide advice to Government on whether a new service should be publicly funded through Medicare using the best available evidence. This process ensures that Australians have access to services that have been shown to be safe and clinically effective, as well as representing value-for-money.
Information on MSAC and the application process is available at www.msac.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Tertiary Education
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 25 July 2023 about a petition presented in the House of Representatives on 7 November 2022, seeking Commonwealth financial support for students undertaking work placements as part of their courses.

Getting more Australians into work remains a key objective for the Australian Government. For those who are studying and need additional help, our income support system is designed to be a safety net. Students who undertake placements as part of their studies may be eligible for student payments such as Youth Allowance or Austudy. To be eligible as a full-time student, a student must be undertaking at least 75 per cent of the normal full-time study load for that course. Practical training or placements off campus can count towards study load if the educational institution gives this component of a course appropriate weighting or recognition as full time study.

The Government recognises that living on income support payments can be challenging, especially with the increases to the cost of living. As part of the Government's $14.6 billion cost-of-living package announced in the 2023-24 Budget, there are changes to income support payments including:
Increasing working age and student payments, including Youth Allowance and Austudy, by $40 per fortnight.
Increasing the maximum rates of Commonwealth Rent Assistance by 15 per cent, which is the largest increase in more than 30 years.
These changes will commence from 20 September 2023.

Beyond income support, the Government has committed to deliver the Australian Universities Accord through a 12-month review of Australia's higher education system, led by a panel of eminent Australians. The Accord Panel is focussing on key priority areas including the affordability of, and contribution arrangements to, higher education.

The Australian Universities Accord Interim Report was released on 19 July 2023. The interim report notes the review 'will explore the possibility of requiring some form of financial support for students undertaking mandatory placements'. The Accord Panel's final report is due to be presented to Government in December 2023. The interim report can be viewed at www.education.gov.au/australian-universities-accord/Resourses/accord-interim-report.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention. I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth (Petition No. EN4166)
Political Advertising
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for referring petition EN4167, transmitted on 25 July 2023, about regulating truth in political advertising. I respond as the Special Minister of State, responsible for electoral matters.

The Labor Party has led federal electoral reform to increase openness in Australia's democratic system. Significantly, the Hawke Government introduced framework for the disclosure of political donations and electoral expenditure. This significant reform laid the groundwork for increased transparency, and Labor continued to pursue more rigorous donation reforms from opposition in 2016.

The Albanese Government remains committed to strengthening the transparency of our electoral system and maintaining voter confidence in elections and referendums. In this pursuit, I am also mindful electoral reform is complex and requires studious consultation across the Parliament. As such, the parliament's multi-partisan Joint Standing Committee of Electoral Reform (JSCEM) is the appropriate forum for proposed electoral changes to be investigated and considered.

Already this term, the Government has updated Australia's referendum legislation to ensure the voter experience at the upcoming referendum is aligned to voters' experience at the last federal election. You will be pleased to know that in keeping with our commitments, our amendments included establishing a financial disclosure regime for referenda, and aligning foreign donation restrictions and authorisation requirements with those of federal elections. This Bill and changes were considered by JSCEM as part of the parliamentary process.

Last year, after JSCEM was constituted for this parliament, I wrote to it requesting its consideration of matters relating to the 2022 federal election. One of the issues I specifically requested it inquire into is the potential for 'truth in political advertising' laws to enhance the integrity and transparency of the electoral system. In its interim report, JSCEM recommended the Federal Government legislate to govern truth in political advertising. JSCEM continues to deliberate in this inquiry with a final report expected later this year; after I have considered its final report and recommendations, I will develop legislation to deliver long overdue reforms to our electoral system.

In addition to legal reforms, there are existing measures undertaken to address misinformation and disinformation in the electoral system. Here the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) takes a proactive role, leading public education and responding to misinformation, as evidenced by their work at the 2022 Federal Election. The AEC is an independent statutory body and is responsible for the conduct and delivery of federal electoral events.

During the 2022 federal election, the AEC ran an expanded 'Stop and Consider' campaign, building on the success of a similar campaign for the 2019 Federal Election. The AEC launched and maintained an Electoral Disinformation Register, which listed prominent electoral mis and disinformation and acted as an informative source. The AEC's work plays a vital role in upholding Australia's electoral reputation despite an ever- more complex operational and communication environment.

If you are interested in JSCEM's progress, including its Interim Report, you can access more information here www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters. Further, if you would like to know more about the role and work of the AEC, you can access their website at www.aec.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention, and I hope this information assists the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
Health Care
Dear Chair

I am writing in response to a petition by the Lactation Consultants of Australia and New Zealand (LCANZ), presented to the Standing Committee on Petitions on 7 November 2022. I apologise for my late reply, this matter has only now been brought to my attention having unfortunately been sent to an incorrect address.

LCANZ's petition requests that grant funding made to the Infant Nutrition Council under the Agricultural Trade and Market Access Cooperation (ATMAC) program be rescinded and used for the implementation of the Australian National Breastfeeding Strategy. LCANZ are represented on the Breastfeeding Export Reference Group who assisted the Department of Health and Aged Care to develop the strategy.

The LCANZ's petition notes the "marketing of infant formula undermines breastfeeding rates, and ... does not require promotion". Please note ATMAC funded activities related to the diversification and expansion of international trade and did not involve the domestic promotion or marketing of infant formula. The ATMAC program played an important role in assisting the sector to respond to both the COVID-19 pandemic and other market disruptions that restricted access to key destination markets.

Applications to the ATMAC program were assessed through a robust process consistent with the Commonwealth Grant Rules and Guidelines. The application period is now closed, and all grant funding was exhausted by the conclusion of the 2022-23 financial year.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt (Petition No. EN4188)
Workplace Relations
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 regarding petition number EN4198, which proposes amendments to the Fair Work Act 2009 to allow employees to access leave to care for or following the death of a pet. I note that due to a technical error, the email was received by my office on 25 July 2023.

The Fair Work Act 2009 establishes a safety net of minimum entitlements for all national system employees, including the National Employment Standards (with leave entitlements to support employees when they become sick or need to take a break from work), the national minimum wage and modern awards. The Act encourages workers and businesses to bargain in good faith to make enterprise agreements that deliver improved terms and conditions for workers and productivity gains for business.

Enterprise agreements can include terms that supplement the minimum entitlements in the National Employment Standards, such as the proposed additional paid bereavement leave. Certain enterprise agreements also provide employees with paid miscellaneous leave for reasons agreed with their employer.
Thank you for bringing this this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke

subdebateinfo.title: World Health Organization, Convention, Agreement or Other International Instrument on Pandemic Prevention, Preparedness and Response, International Health Regulations

p.span: World Health Organization
Convention, Agreement or Other International Instrument on Pandemic Prevention, Preparedness and Response
International Health Regulations
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Ministerial Petitions EN4203, EN4255, EN4266, EN4236, EN5009, EN5028, EN5029, EN5048.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is, and remains, a Member State-led organisation. Let me assure you that under international law, Member States such as Australia retain sovereignty regarding their public health policies. The WHO has no legal authority to force countries to accept any of its recommendations and can only provide aid and assistance at Member States' request The intent of the new instrument is to strengthen the international community's efforts in s. Australian law can only be changed by an act of the Parliament, not by any international treaty or other legal instrument.

The Australian Government is dedicated to strengthening national and global pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, and is committed to working with the Australian public and the international community to be better prepared for the next pandemic. As referred to in the Ministerial Petitions referenced above, two major reforms through the WHO are being considered: the development of a new international instrument on pandemic preparedness, prevention and response, such as a treaty; and targeted amendments to strengthen the implementation of the International Health Regulations (2005) (IHR). These processes will work to close gaps identified through independent reviews of the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The intent of the new instrument is to strengthen the international community's efforts in preventing, preparing for and responding to future pandemics. The new instrument provides an opportunity to reduce the risk and impact of health threats, such as that posed by COVID-19 by strengthening global health systems and disease surveillance, while enhancing equity and future pandemic response. Australia is actively engaged in the Intergovernmental Negotiating Body (INB), which is drafting and negotiating the new instrument. For further information about the work of the INB please visit https://apps.who.int/gb/inb.

This new instrument is distinct from the IHR. The IHR is an existing legal framework that defines countries rights and obligations in handling infectious disease outbreaks, public events and emergencies that have the potential to cross borders. In May 2022, Member States, including Australia, agreed at the World Health Assembly to establish a working group to consider targeted amendments to the IHR—the Working Group on Amendments to the IHR (WGIHR).

These amendments will enable the IHR to remain responsive to evolving public health threats and strengthen the ability of countries to co-operate internationally to prepare for and respond to infectious disease outbreaks. Australia is actively participating in negotiations through the WGIHR. Further information about the work of the WGIHR is available at www.who.int/health-topics/international-health-regulations.

We are working across both negotiation processes to ensure that reforms align with Government priorities and the national interest. The Government will consult widely across government, with Australian stakeholders and the community throughout negotiations to ensure Australia's and our region's interests are preserved and our priorities advanced.

Any new instrument or amendments to the IHR will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and consideration by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties (JSCOT). This includes Article 59 of the IHR, which was agreed by WHO Member States at the World Health Assembly in 2022. As part of its process in scrutinising proposed treaties, JSCOT undertakes further consultation by inviting submissions from stakeholders and members of the public. Any changes to Australian law to implement the new instrument or IHR amendments would also have to be considered and passed by Parliament.

It is important to note that the Australian Constitution can only be changed by referendum, which requires a public vote by the people of Australia in accordance with the requirements of section 128 of the Constitution. The Government is not considering a referendum be held on this matter at this time.
Further information about the above global health reform processes is available at www.health.gov.au/our-work/strengthening-global-health-and-international-pandemic-response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Sri Lanka
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email regarding EN4213 requesting individuals to be designated under the Autonomous Sanctions Amendment Regulations 2011 for serious corruption in Sri Lanka. I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government is strongly opposed to corruption in all its forms. Australia has a strong record of global, regional and domestic action to prevent and expose corrupt activity. Australian law enforcement and intelligence agencies are also working to stem the flow of illicit wealth into Australia.

The government welcomes engagement with civil society on thematic sanctions and keeps its thematic sanctions frameworks under regular review. Consistent with longstanding government policy, we do not speculate on possible sanctions listings.
I thank the Petitions Committee for highlighting these concerns.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong

subdebateinfo.title: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action

p.span: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN4242 presented to the House of Representatives on 7 November 2022, regarding the Intergovernmental Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government recognises young people's resilience, strength, and capacity to lead positive change, and believes that young people should be involved in the decisions that affect their lives and futures. Young Australians will feel the greatest effects of unmitigated climate change and are uniquely positioned to develop the solutions we need to combat the climate crisis. It is vital their input is sought and carefully considered on an issue inexorably linked to their futures, and that their perspectives are used to shape climate action that is inclusive, sustainable, and ambitious.

The Sharm el-Sheikh Implementation Plan agreed at COP27 recognised the role of children and youth as agents of change in addressing and responding to climate change. It encouraged Parties to include children and youth in their processes for designing and implementing climate policy and action, and, as appropriate, to consider including young representatives and negotiators into their national delegations, recognizing the importance of intergenerational equity and maintaining the stability of the climate system for future generations.

Australia also welcomed the adoption of a four-year Action Plan under the Glasgow work programme on Action for Climate Empowerment (ACE). The Action Plan sets out short-term, clear, and time-bound activities in the four priority areas of the work programme and across the six elements of ACE in a balanced manner as a concrete step towards empowering all members of society, including children and youth, to engage in climate action. Australia is committed to taking actions to empower the voices of young people to drive ambitious climate action.

In line with this, the Australian Government recognises the participation of young Australians in climate action is key to our transition to becoming a clean energy economy and Australia's future as a renewable energy powerhouse. Australia is committed to promoting youth voices in international climate engagement, including at COP28.

Australia's Office for Youth, with support from the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water, has established a Youth Advisory Group on Climate Change and COP28. This group is providing advice to the Australian Government and has been established to focus on our engagement on climate change internationally, specifically in relation to COP28 in Dubai in November, and Australia's bid to co-host COP31 with the Pacific.

In addition to the Youth Advisory Group, the Australian Government continues to actively engage with a range of other youth groups, including Australian Youth for International Climate Engagement (AYFICE), Global Voices and UNICEF.

Finally, later this year UNICEF and Monash University will partner to host an Australian Local Conference of Youth (LCOY) that will empower young Australians to contribute to the Conference of Youth (COY) held just before COP28.
We remain committed to empowering and supporting young Australians to continue to demonstrate leadership on climate action.
Yours sincerely
cc: Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy Senator the Hon Jenny McAllister
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4248 on Medicare levy payments. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Medicare levy was introduced to help offset the Australian Government's increased spending on health following the introduction of Medicare in 1984. The levy contributes to the Government's ability to fund the cost of Australia's public health system, in the same way as other sources of revenue such as income tax. The Medicare levy is currently imposed at a flat rate of 2 per cent on a person's taxable income.

However, the Medicare levy low-income thresholds ensure that households do not pay Medicare levy if their taxable income is below a certain level, and the amount payable is phased-in over a certain income range.

Taxpayers with income between the low-income threshold and the phase-in limit pay a concessional amount of Medicare levy, which is determined as 10 per cent of taxable income exceeding the low-income threshold, and only begin to pay the full 2 per cent when their income exceeds the phase-in limit.

There are different low-income thresholds and phase-in limits for singles, couples, families with children, and seniors and pensioners. In 2022-23, a single person with no children will not be liable for Medicare levy if their taxable income does not exceed $24,276. A single person pays a concessional amount of Medicare levy if their income is above $24,276, and only pays the full 2 per cent when their income exceeds $30,345.

These arrangements ensure that the liability of residents to pay the Medicare levy reflects their financial capacity to contribute to the total cost of national health care. This treatment is consistent with the progressive nature of the Australian income tax system, that is, those with higher incomes pay a larger share of tax.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Family Law
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your petition EN4267 dated 7 November 2022, concerning child support. I apologise for the lengthy delay in responding.

The Australian Government acknowledges the causes of suicide are complex and that reducing the number of lives lost requires the combined efforts of all governments and communities to address individual, social and economic drivers of distress. The National Suicide Prevention Office is coordinating a whole-of-government response and developing a National Suicide Prevention Strategy which will address the social determinants of suicide, with a focus on communities who are disproportionately impacted by these issues.

The Government is aware of the difficulties that are faced by parents who experience family breakdown, including the stress of disputes in relation to child support. The Government intends for the Child Support scheme to be fair to ensure children are financially supported by both parents.

A key principle of the Child Support scheme is that parents share in the costs of supporting their children according to their financial capacity. For this reason, child support assessments are generally based on the child support formula, which calculates how much child support is payable by considering each parents' income, the number, ages, and care arrangements for the children in the assessment.

Additional income such as overtime is included for child support purposes, which generally results in child support payments increase to reflect the change in circumstances. This policy helps to ensure parents are supporting their children in line with their financial capacities at any given time.

The child support formula determines how much child support is payable by calculating each parent's child support percentage. A parent's child support percentage represents the share of the costs of the children they are required to meet, based on their share of combined income, and less their contribution to the costs of the children through care. If a parent's child support percentage is greater than zero, they will be liable to pay child support.

This means that where both parents have equal care of a child, but different incomes, one parent may be required to pay child support. The child support formula is designed in this way to ensure that children are supported by both parents in accordance with their financial capacity (that is, the formula does not quarantine part of one parent's income from being assessed because they have equal shared care).

The petitioner may be interested to know that in the 2023-24 Budget, the Government committed $5.1 million to implement key child support recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Australia's Family Law System (committee). The key interests of the committee were to ensure the Child Support scheme balances the interests of separated parents, reflects current community standards, and importantly, continue supporting the best interests of children. The committee's report and the Government's response (tabled on 25 January 2023) is available at
.www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Family_Law_System.

As part of the Government's response to the committee's recommendations, the Government agreed to a range of recommendations to improve the Child Support Scheme over the longer term, including the following:

The Government has established a Child Support Stakeholder Consultation Group who will perform a key advisory role for Government on a range of policy and service delivery issues that impact the efficient operation of the Scheme, and positive outcomes for separated parents.

In response to Recommendations 14, 18 and 19 of the Committee's Third Interim Report, the Government has agreed to establish a Child Support Expert Panel, and commission research into the costs of raising children in Australia. The Expert Panel will review the costs of children findings to make recommendations on whether and how to update the Costs of the Children Table (and formula), including the self-support amount.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022, received on the 25 July 2023 regarding House of Representatives Petition EN4324, requesting to reinstate Play Therapy on the list of National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) funded therapeutic supports. I am sorry for a technical issue by the House of Representatives that caused the delayed response.

In recent updates to the NDIS Pricing Arrangements and Price Limits (NDIS PAPL) there were some revisions made to the support items for Early Childhood Supports (for participants younger than 7) and Therapy Supports (for participants 7 or older).

The National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) sets out the basis for these changes in section 6.8 of the 2021-22 Annual Pricing Review (APL), which can be found on the NDIS website at www.ndis.gov.au/providers/pricing-arrangements/making-pricing-decisions/pricing-review-archive#pricing-review-documents-2021-22
The APL proposed the following recommendations to support greater clarity about the types of professionals able to claim for therapy support and early childhood support items:

Recommendation 22—To provide greater clarity to participants, the NDIA should amend the NDIS PAPL to include clear definitions of the types of therapists that are able to make claims for therapy support items, including the qualifying criteria for each type of therapist as set out in this report.

Recommendation 23—To provide greater clarity to participants, the NDIA should create separate support items for each type of therapist in both the early childhood supports and therapy sections of the NDIS PAPL.

Delivering on the recommendations of the APL, the updates made to the NDIS PAPL describe the types of professionals that can deliver supports, in line with the NDIS Quality and Safeguarding Commission's requirements for Early Childhood Supports and for Therapy Supports.

The professionals who can deliver supports are listed in the NDIS PAPL 2023-24 and can be found on the NDIS website at www.ndis.gov.au/providers/pricing-arrangements. Music Therapist is included in the list for Therapy Supports, but not in Early Childhood Supports. Play Therapist is not included in either list. However, there is provision for a person who is not one of the types of professionals specifically listed in NDIS PAPL to be able to deliver supports so long as they meet the requirements set out under Early Childhood Supports—Other Professional, or Therapy Supports—Other Professional. The types of professionals who can deliver supports include:

Early Childhood Supports—Other Professional—A person who is not one of the types of professionals listed but who has a Bachelor's degree or higher in their relevant area and holds current registration or membership with their relevant registration and or professional body. It is expected that the person delivers supports in line with the NDIS Commission's NDIS Practice Standards and Quality Indicators for Early Childhood Supports.

Therapy Supports—Other Professional—A person who is not one of the types of professionals listed but who the provider considers to be an appropriate professional to deliver therapeutic supports in line with the NDIS Quality and Safeguarding Commission's requirements for the Therapeutic Supports Registration Group.

The NDIS PAPL does not describe what type of therapy can or cannot be delivered from these professionals as part of these supports. The NDIS provides funding for Early Childhood Supports or Therapy Supports to participants based on their individual support needs. Decisions about including funded supports in an NDIS plan are determined by the support needs of the NDIS participant and they are set out in the plan developed with them. The type of support depends on the needs of the child with developmental delay or disability and the preferences of their family about how these supports are delivered and who delivers them.

The NDIS Commission provides information, resources and support to NDIS providers about how to meet their obligations under the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 when delivering support services to NDIS participants.
I trust this information is of assistance to you. Yours sincerely,
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Shorten
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your petition EN4342 of 7 November 2022 to the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services, the Hon Bill Shorten MP, regarding child support. The petition was referred to me as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the lengthy delay in responding.

The Australian Government is aware of the difficulties that are faced by parents who experience family breakdown, including the stress of disputes in relation to child support. The Government intends for the Child Support scheme to be fair to ensure children are financially supported by both parents.

A key principle of the Child Support scheme is that parents share in the costs of supporting their children according to their financial capacity. For this reason, child support assessments are generally based on the child support formula, which calculates how much child support is payable by considering each parents' income, the number, ages, and care arrangements for the children in the assessment.

The child support formula uses the Costs of the Children Table which identifies the costs of the children based on the parents' combined child support income as well as the number and age of the children in the assessment. The Costs of the Children Table was based on extensive research into how much parents spend on children. The research found that expenditure on children is different in households with different income levels, numbers of children and children of different ages.

More information on the research can be found in the publication In the Best Interests of Children -Reforming the Child Support Scheme at www.dss.gov.au/our-resgonsibilities/families-and-children/publications-articles.

The petitioner may be interested to know that in the 2023-24 Budget, the Government committed $5.1 million to implement key child support recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Australia's Family Law System (committee). The key interests of the committee were to ensure the Child Support scheme balances the interests of separated parents, reflects current community standards and, importantly, continues supporting the best interests of children. The committee's report and the Government's response (tabled on 25 January 2023) are available at
.www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Family_Law_System.

As part of the Government's response to the committee's recommendations, the Government agreed to a range of recommendations to improve the Child Support Scheme over the longer term, including the following:

The Government has established a Child Suppo1t Stakeholder Consultation Group who will perform a key advisory role for Government on a range of policy and service delivery issues that impact the efficient operation of the Scheme, and positive outcomes for separated parents.

In response to Recommendations 14, 18 and 19 of the Committee's Third Interim Report, the Government has agreed to establish a Child Support Expert Panel, and commission research into the costs of raising children in Australia. The Expert Panel will review the costs of children findings to make recommendations on whether and how to update the Costs of the Children Table (and formula), including the self-support amount.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Oil and Gas Exploration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 23 November 2022 to the Hon Tanya Plibersek MP, Minister for the Environment and Water, presenting petition number EN4404 relating to seismic testing in Australian waters. Your email was referred to me on 21 August 2023 as the Minister responsible for Resources.

The Australian Government is committed to protecting our marine environment and enforcing safe and environmentally sustainable practices by the oil and gas sector, now and in the future. Seismic testing in Australia is regulated by Australia's independent expert regulator, the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority (NOPSEMA). NOPSEMA's staff include qualified technical experts with extensive experience in offshore environmental impact and risk management, marine ecology, and environmental science.

A proposed seismic survey cannot proceed unless the impacts and risks associated with the activity have been evaluated and controls adopted to reduce those impacts and risks to as low as reasonably practicable and acceptable levels. If the environmental impacts of a specific seismic survey cannot be managed, NOPSEMA will not allow the activity to proceed. Where the scientific understanding of the potential impacts of a seismic survey is limited, NOPSEMA applies precaution to its regulatory decision-making.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Your sincerely
from the Minister for Resources, Ms Madeleine King
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 8 November 2022, received on the 25 July 2023 regarding Petition EN4457—NDIS funding extension for children turning 7 in 2022. I am sorry for a technical issue by the House of Representatives that caused the delayed response.

The National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) has a number of COVID-19 measures in place. The NDIA continues to support participants and their families to receive the disability support they need from the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS); and to ensure NDIS providers are equipped to offer these supports, including during periods where the continuity of those supports has been affected by COVID-19 restrictions. These measures have been and continue to support NDIS participants to access the early intervention services funded in their plans, where those supports may have been disrupted due to COVID-19.

Families who have not been able to use funding in their child's plan or have used less funding because of COVID-19 disruptions will not be disadvantaged with their next plan. Their next plan will set out the goals and include the disability-related supports their child requires. They will not have their disability support needs assessed against the expenditure of funds from any previous plan. The funds available in their current plan will continue to be available, including those funds that may have been unspent due to COVID-19 impacts. Until such time as the plan is replaced with the child's next NDIS Plan.
Some of the COVID-19 measures that have continued to be available to NDIS participants include:

Accessing supports—Participants can use their existing NDIS funds to buy low-cost assistive technology, such as smart devices, to help access supports. Families who have concerns about accessing NDIS supports for their children are encouraged to contact their NDIS provider in the first instance.

The provider may be able to suggest different ways to deliver the support, such as using telehealth. In those circumstances the child may benefit form the opportunity to access additional technologies.

Supports for providers—The NDIA has a number of supports in place to assist all NDIS providers, when they are experiencing serious workforce disruptions. The purpose of this support is to enable NDIS providers to make alternative workforce arrangements to facilitate continuity in supports.

The NDIA provides information to NDIS participants and NDIS providers about the additional support that is available in response to COVID-19 on its website. Families can contact their 'my NDIS contact' listed on their NDIS plan or call the NDIS call centre on 1800 800 110 for assistance or if they have concerns about their child's plan.

The NDIA continues to work closely with other Australian Government agencies and state and territory governments to support NDIS participants to access supports and services that may be affected by COVID-19.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Shorten
Higher Education Contribution Scheme
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 November 2022 regarding petition referral EN4474 on unpaid, full-time, mandatory placement requirements in university degrees. I understand that due to a technical error, there was a delay in a number of petitions reaching my office.

The Australian Government acknowledges the difficulties many students experience with meeting the cost of living while studying and completing mandatory placements. Through the 2023-24 Budget, the Government increased support available through Austudy, ABSTUDY, Youth Allowance and provided access to more Government Rent Assistance. These payments support Australians of all ages to attend university.

I recognise the current system may not enable some Australians to access or complete a higher education degree. This is why the Government is committed to delivering an Australian Universities Accord through a review of the higher education system. The Accord Panel has released its interim report, which acknowledges the challenges associated with unpaid student placements, particularly on students from low SES and regional backgrounds and students who have caring responsibilities. The Accord Panel is exploring the possibility of requiring some form of financial support for students undertaking mandatory placements.
The Accord Panel is continuing to develop and explore their considerations in the lead up to the Accord Final Report, which will be delivered to the Government in December 2023.
Further information about the Accord and a copy of the Interim Report can be found on the Department of Education's website at www.education.gov.au/australian-universities-accord.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare

from the Minister for the Arts, Mr Burke (Petition No. EN4480)

subdebateinfo.title: Arts and Culture: Cartoons and Animation

p.span: Arts and Culture: Cartoons and Animation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter of 28 November 2022, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning the digital distribution and transmission of anime, Petition EN4484.
I acknowledge the concerns about children and young people becoming addicted to particular forms of media raised in the petition.

The Government is serious about online safety and protecting children and young people from harmful content, and has a range of measures in place. The Government's view is that content should be regulated consistently and that outright bans for specific forms or genres of content are not appropriate.

Under the National Classification Scheme, films, computer games and certain publications, including those accessed online, must be classified before they can be legally made available to the Australian public. Films and computer games are given a classification to indicate suitable audience, and consumer advice to provide information about the strongest content.

Some classifications are age-restricted, providing additional protections. For films, content that is classified MA15+ is restricted to persons 15 years and over unless the person is accompanied by an adult. Content that is classified R18+ is legally restricted to adults aged 18 years and over. For films there is also an Xl8+ category that is specific to sexually explicit content (pornography).
Any film, computer game or publication with content that falls outside generally-accepted community standards is refused classification (RC) and cannot be legally sold or distributed in Australia.

The hosting of online material by Australian online service providers is regulated under the Online Safety Act 2021 (the Act). The eSafety Commissioner has powers to request or require takedown of illegal and restricted online content. For example, the eSafety Commissioner can respond to X18+ material hosted in Australia by issuing a removal notice to the service provider. For other material that is not appropriate for children such as material classified as Rl8+, the eSafety Commissioner can require that it be placed behind a Restricted Access System to limit its access to those aged 18 and above.
Under the Online Content Scheme, the eSafety Commissioner also has powers to remove the 'worst of the worst' kinds of illegal and harmful content, no matter where it's hosted.

The eSafety Commissioner can assess content, and if it is likely that the material would be refused classification, eSafety can issue a notice to compel service providers to remove it. Service providers that fail to act on an eSafety notice within 24 hours can be liable for significant financial penalties. Furthermore, eSafety can seek a Federal Court order to remove access to online services that continually disregard eSafety notices.

Under the Act, industry is also being expected to do more to keep Australians safe, particularly children. The Act requires that online service providers develop updated industry codes to address harmful online content. The eSafety Commissioner is currently working with the industry to develop these codes.

To assist parents and carers to keep their children safe, the eSafety Commissioner also provides a range of online safety resources for parents and young people, providing parents with up-to-date information about parental controls and software tools that can limit what children do or see online. This includes options to filter different kinds of content, such as age-inappropriate content. Free online webinars, downloadable books, information sheets and resources with easy to follow advice can be found at www.esafety.gov.au/parents.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this response is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022, on behalf of the Petitions Committee reference number EN4493, regarding a transition to a Republic government with an inclusion of a multicultural council.
The Albanese Labor Government believes that our nation's Constitution is a living document which should be amended to reflect contemporary Australia and to embody Australian values.

The Albanese Government's priority for Constitutional reform remains recognition of First Nations peoples in the Australian Constitution, including an enshrined Voice to Parliament, as outlined in the Uluru Statement from the Heart.

The Government supports and will work towards establishing an Australian Republic with an Australian head of state. Each and every Australian, no matter their background, birthplace, gender or religion should be able to aspire to be our nation's head of state.
The Albanese Government will continue to consult the Australian people, including on potential models for an Australian Republic.

While I have been appointed Assistant Minister for the Republic to advance the debate on an Australian head of state, Constitutional recognition and a Voice to Parliament for First Nations people remain the Government's Constitutional reform priority.
Thank you for bringing petition EN4493 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for the Republic, Mr Thistlethwaite
Education Workforce
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 regarding Petition-EN4521.

There is no more important job than being a teacher and Australia needs more of them. That is why the Government is committed to supporting alternative pathways into teaching, including for mid-career entrants. Alternative pathways broaden the entry points into the teaching profession by allowing individuals to work while they complete their teaching qualification. The Government is supporting these diverse entry points into teaching through a range of mechanisms, including the High Achieving Teachers (HAT) Program.
The HAT Program offers 2 alternative, employment-based pathways into teaching for high-achieving individuals committed to pursuing a career in the teaching profession.

The Government currently contracts Teach For Australia and La Trobe University under the HAT Program. These programs fast-track participants into classrooms and enable them to earn a salary while completing a Master's qualification. Each pathway proactively recruits and selects high-achieving graduates with the knowledge, skills and experience that schools need. Program participants are placed in teaching positions in Australian secondary schools experiencing teacher workforce shortages and receive a high degree of training and support.

Further, all Education Ministers agreed to the National Teacher Workforce Action Plan (the Action Plan) on 15 December 2022, which includes actions designed to increase the number of people choosing to become teachers and ensure that existing teachers remain in the profession. Under the Action Plan, the HAT Program will be expanded with an additional 1,500 places to encourage more professionals to switch careers to teaching.

Under Action 9 of the Action Plan, the Australian Council of Deans of Education is developing a framework in consultation with Universities Australia, higher education providers and teacher regulatory authorities to recognise previous study, work experience and skills that may be transferable to teaching.

The framework will include measures to ensure First Nations people, mid-career professionals and paraprofessionals can have their skills, expertise and prior learning recognised through credit towards their qualification, while maintaining robust teacher qualification requirements.

Further, under Action 8 of the Action Plan, the Government established the Teacher Education Expert Panel (the Panel) in September 2022 to provide advice on how to improve initial teacher education (ITE) to better prepare beginning teachers for the classroom.
The final report of the Panel was released on 6 July 2023. Education Ministers have provided in-principle support for all 14 recommendations, designed to:
strengthen ITE programs to deliver confident, effective beginning teachers (recommendations 1-3)
strengthen the link between performance and funding of ITE programs (recommendations 4--7)
improve the quality of practical teaching experience (recommendations 8-11)
enhance postgraduate ITE programs for mid-career entrants (recommendations 12-14).

The Panel did not recommend returning to a one-year Graduate Diploma of Education as a way of accelerating entry into the profession, as it did not consider this was academically or professionally proportionate with the complexity and status of teaching. The Panel did, however, recommend that more high-quality mid-career programs, such as employment-based and accelerated pathways, should be developed and scaled using the flexibility within existing regulatory arrangements.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Pedestrian and Bicycle Infrastructure
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 6 February 2023 regarding petition EN4650, the recognition of the importance of pedestrian and bike infrastructure and its benefits. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government makes significant investments in land transport infrastructure across Australia through its infrastructure investment pipeline, including for projects which include active transport components. The Government recognises that active transport not only contributes towards creating positive health and wellbeing outcomes, but also supports the tourism sector and drives economic development more broadly.

In recognition of the multiple benefits of active transport, the Government works closely with state and territory and local governments on the selection and development of road infrastructure projects with active transport components. However, it is important to recognise that the design, project deployment and funding of cycling and pedestrian infrastructure is primarily the responsibility of state and territory and local governments.

The Government has committed $976.4 million to the Road Safety Program (RSP) over the next two financial years, to fund projects via the state and territory governments to deliver road safety upgrades across the National Road Network. These projects will include delivery of upgrades and improvements for vulnerable road users, particularly on urban footpaths and cycleways, reducing risk of serious injury and road crashes, which align with the key priorities of the National Road Safety Strategy 2021-30 and the National Road Safety Action Plan 2023- 25.

To improve protections for footpath and cycleway users, and to reduce fatalities and serious injuries, RSP funding recipients must present projects that improve safety for vulnerable road users and demonstrate how these treatments will increase safety, particularly on footpaths and cycleways.

Up to 20% of urban works funding under the RSP must be dedicated to safety treatments that focus on protections for pedestrians and cyclists. This may include separation of cyclists from vehicles and pedestrians, protections for mobility vehicles, cyclists and pedestrians and School Zone projects. Funding recipients are also strongly encouraged to consider works for vulnerable road users in regional and remote locations. No minimum threshold will be applied to these types of projects.
Current examples of Government investments in significant road infrastructure projects with active transport components include:
$1.2 billion for the upgrade of the Northern Road in Western Sydney, which includes nearly 36 kilometres of shared pedestrian and cycling paths;
$1.75 billion towards delivering the No1th East Link, which includes 34 kilometres of new walking and cycling paths, green bridges, and upgraded reserves and community parklands;

$510 million for the Pacific Motorway: Eight Mile Plains to Daisy Hill Upgrade project which includes a V1 Veloway (cycleway) that has been extended by four kilometres with a further section expected to be opened by late 2024; and

$14.26 million towards upgrades on Henderson Road and Kelletts Road intersection and the Henderson Road and Ferntree Gully Road in Knoxfield in Victoria, which includes installation of green pavement in cycling lanes at conflict points.

Notably, the $3.25 billion Local Roads and Community Infrastructure (LRCI) Program also supports local councils to deliver priority local road and community infrastructure projects across Australia, supporting jobs and delivering benefits to local communities. Since 2020, more than 10,000 projects have been approved under Phases 1-4. Approximately 33 per cent of all LRCI projects are road projects, 62 per cent are community infrastructure and 5 per cent involve a combination of road and community upgrades. Of these, approximately 8 per cent will contribute to active transport such as upgrades to cycling or walking paths.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Parliamentary Petitions
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence referring petition EN4687, which requests that the House of Representatives make changes to its petitions system to improve public accountability for government responses to petitions. I apologise for the delay in responding, due to the delayed transmission of the petition to my office.

Firstly, I note that there are accountability measures in the current House petitions system. As you know, the Petitions Committee is empowered under Standing Order 209 to refer a petition to the Minister responsible for the administration of the matters raised in the petition. The Minister is then expected to provide a written response within 90 days. I understand that the Committee is currently reviewing its procedures for the referral of petitions to Ministers and, I'm sure, will report any changes to the House in due course.

Another important accountability measure is the publication of petitions and Ministers' responses to petitions on the Parliament's website at: www.aph.gov.au/e-petitions. Once presented in the House, all petitions and responses are published on the website. This allows members of the public to easily track petitions and the government's response.

The right of petitioning Parliament remains a fundamental right of citizens and the only means by which the individual can directly place grievances before Parliament. I certainly encourage all Australians to consider using the petitions process to bring matters to the attention of the Parliament.
Thank you for writing to me on this matter.
Yours Faithfully,
from the Speaker, Mr Dick
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4700, with 44 signatures, concerning the points test for General Skilled Migration visas in relation to partner qualification requirements. My apologies for the delay in responding.
Under the points test, an applicant's points score at the time they are invited to apply must be not less than the indicative points score in the applicant's Expression of Interest.

This is designed to preserve the integrity of the invitation process ensuring that those with the most points are invited first and to ensure applicants do not overstate their self-assessed points score in order to obtain an invitation.

In the current points test system, applicants are not excluded on the basis of establishing a new relationship, however their points score may be affected according to the skill and English level of their new partner.

The additional points for applicants who do not have a spouse or de facto partner, or applicants who have a spouse or de facto partner who is an Australian permanent resident or an Australian citizen, ensure a single person with identical skills to a primary applicant who has a skilled spouse or de facto partner will not be displaced in the points test.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, released 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia—Outline of the Government's Migration Strategy , which foreshadows a number of reforms to policy settings in the migration system, including the redesign of the points test. https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/programs- subsite/files/migration-strategy-outline.pdf
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4700 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Foreign Investment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4776 on a freeze on all purchases of Australian land and businesses by foreign interests. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Petition EN4776 raises concerns regarding foreign ownership of Australian land and assets. The petition asks that a freeze be put on all purchases of Australian land & businesses by foreign interests.

Foreign investment provides significant benefits to Australia. It is important national priority areas, including building infrastructure, developing our critical minerals and critical technologies capabilities, boosting Australia's manufacturing capabilities and delivering the large-scale clean energy transition.

Australia's foreign investment regime strikes a balance between ensuring that we attract critical investment to support our growth, while maintaining community confidence in foreign investment and upholding our national interest. While Australia welcomes foreign investment, the Government recognises that we have a responsibility to ensure incoming investment is not contrary to our national interest (including national security). Investment proposals are examined on a risk-based approach and in light of various criteria for assessing the national interest (e.g. impact on the economy and community, competition, character of the investor, and other government policies such as tax and impact on national security).

The Government's policy regarding foreign investment in residential property is to channel foreign investment into new residential dwellings, as opposed to established dwellings, so as to create additional jobs in the construction industry and to bolster Australia's housing stock. Foreign persons generally require foreign investment approval before acquiring an interest in residential land and are also generally prohibited from purchasing established housing.

There is an exception for temporary residents, who will generally be allowed to purchase one established dwelling to use as their principal place of residence while they live in Australia. If a temporary resident is approved to purchase an established dwelling, it will generally be approved with a number of conditions attached to that approval, one of which is that the temporary resident must sell, transfer, or otherwise dispose of their interest in the property within six months from when it ceases to be their principal place of residence, or they cease to be a temporary resident (other than by becoming a permanent resident), whichever occurs first. Temporary residents are also required to pay application fees which start at $13,200 for residential properties up to $1 million and increase in increments of $13,200 for each additional $1 million of consideration.

The Australian Taxation Office is responsible for screening foreign investment in residential real estate and monitoring compliance. It has an effective compliance program to detect failures by foreign persons to apply for approval and where they breach conditions in their approvals. Since taking office, the Government has, in addition to doubling foreign investment application fees, doubled penalties for breaches of the foreign investment framework relating to residential property.

Foreign acquisitions of Australian agricultural land or agricultural land entities will generally not be granted unless Australian investors are offered an equal opportunity to invest in that land or entity through an open and transparent sales process. Foreign government investors require approval for all acquisitions of agricultural land, regardless of their cumulative holdings or the consideration of the proposed investment.

Maintaining strong compliance with Australia's foreign investment legislation is a priority for the Australian Government, to ensure that foreign investment is not contrary to the national interest (including national security).
Our compliance and enforcement powers allow us to prevent, identify and respond to instances of non- compliance, and include the power to direct investors to take or cease particular actions.
Further information on the foreign investment review framework can be found at: foreigninvestment.gov.au.

Further information on the guidance notes relating to agriculture and business can be found at:
.foreigninvestment.gov.au/guidance/types-of-investments.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Coal Seam Gas Mining
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 March 2023 to the Minister for Resources, the Hon Madeleine King MP, concerning petition EN4806 on fracking in the Surat Basin, Queensland. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities as the Minister for the Environment and Water.

Any new gas development referred to my department will be subject to a rigorous, evidence-based assessment of its likely impacts on matters protected under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Where relevant, this also includes consideration of potential impacts from greenhouse gas emissions on matters protected under the EPBC Act. Proposals must receive all necessary environmental approvals before they can proceed and proponents should also work with relevant communities and First Nations peoples to realise social and economic benefits.
Regarding chemical contamination risks, assessments under the EPBC Act consider the risks of chemicals used during coal seam gas operations and ensure they are appropriately managed.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Renewable Energy
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 about a petition lodged with the Standing Committee on Petitions (petition number EN4826) calling for a parliamentary inquiry in relation to the Chalumbin Wind Farm project, Ravenshoe, Queensland.

I understand that the community has concerns regarding the Chalumbin Windfarm project. The project is being assessed by a public environment report (PER) under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). The EPBC Act process will ensure adequate consideration of the issues identified in the request for parliamentary inquiry. These issues include concerns around environmental impacts, community consultation, and impacts on communities and cultural heritage.

The PER assessment approach requires the proponent to undertake a rigorous environmental assessment of all potential impacts on matters protected under the EBPC Act. As required under the EPBC Act, the public were provided an opportunity to comment on the draft PER, with comments due by 9 January 2023. The proponent is required to summarise the public comments and address them in the final PER.
All relevant information on the impacts of the project, public comments, and social and economic matters will be considered when a decision on whether to approve the project is made.
Thank you again for your correspondence.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Feral Animal Management: Horses
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 17 May 2023 to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator the Hon Murray Watt, about petition EN4827 proposing Commonwealth heritage recognition and protection of brumbies. Your email has been referred to me as the Minister for the Environment and Water, as the matter you have raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As you would be aware, the debate about brumbies, or feral horses, has particularly focussed on their presence in the Australian Alps, which is listed and protected as a National Heritage place under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act).

While I recognise the connection some Australians have with these horses, their presence in the Australian Alps threatens National Heritage values, listed threatened species and ecological communities, and wetlands of international importance ( Ramsar sites), all of which are protected under the EPBC Act as matters of national environmental significance. Specifically, feral horses are known to trample bogs and wetlands, spread weeds, overgraze grasslands and erode waterways. The impact that invasive vertebrate pests, including horses, have on native species is reflected in the listing of 'novel biota and their impact on biodiversity' as a key threatening process under the EPBC Act.

As you would be aware, on 9 February 2023, following a motion by Senator David Pocock, the Senate referred the impacts and management of feral horses in the Australian Alps for inquiry and report by 29 September 2023. The inquiry will be conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment and Communications.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water has provided a submission to the inquiry. It can be accessed at submission 23 on the inquiry's webpage
.www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Environment_and_Communications/FeralHorses47/Submissions. The submission highlights the Australian Government's position that feral horses are impacting matters protected under Australia's national environmental legislation. There is an urgent need for the land managers to actively manage feral horse numbers through improved implementation of existing legislation, policies and plans for the protection of the environment and heritage in the Australian Alps.

Protecting Australia's unique environment is important to the Australian Government and to the people of Australia. The Australian Government does not support the protection of feral horses as a heritage value.
I welcome the inquiry to ensure that we are doing everything we can to effectively protect our precious alpine environment from the impacts of feral horses.
I thank the Standing Committee on Petitions for bringing this matter to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
cc: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Senator the Hon Murray Watt
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
COVID-19: Testing
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 regarding petition number EN4859 requesting the reinstatement of the no referral policy from a medical practitioner for PCR tests at pathology or swab collection sites.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting effective COVID-19 testing to limit the spread and ensure that those most at risk of severe disease, including people with complex underlying health conditions and the immunocompromised, have fast access to care and treatments.

I refer you to my 19 April 2023 response to petition number EN4688. In that response, I indicated that access to COVID-19 PCR tests funded under the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) has remained unchanged throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. A request (referral) from a medical or nurse practitioner has always been a requirement for MBS funded COVID-19 tests (like all other MBS funded pathology tests). A request for a pathology test, including a COVID-19 test, can be made through a telehealth consultation.

Throughout the pandemic, states and territories have conducted COVID-19 PCR testing without the need for a request. The National Partnership on COVID-19 Response has provided states and territories with funding for PCR testing on a 50:50 cost shared basis. This Partnership ceased on 31 December 2022. In accordance with the testing strategy outlined in the National COVID-19 Health Management Plan (National Plan) for 2023, from 1 January 2023, the new National Partnership for Priority Populations for Testing and Vaccination provides funding to states and territories on a 50:50 cost-shared basis to target PCR testing to those most at risk of severe COVID-19 and death, including the immunocompromised. The National Plan can be viewed on the Department of Health and www.health.gov.au by searching for 'National COVID-19 Health Management Plan for 2023'.

Under both the previous and the new National Partnership arrangements, people do not need a referral to access a PCR test through a state and territory testing clinic. State and territory governments continue to provide PCR testing for vulnerable persons who are at risk of severe COVID-19 disease and who are eligible for access to antiviral treatments at state and territory health facilities. Patients who need antivirals can also obtain them through a telehealth consultation and a positive rapid antigen test.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence 18 May 2023 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, enclosing Petition EN4863 with 3261 signatures, concerning asylum for individuals with non-conforming in traditional gender identities. Your correspondence has been referred to me as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to compassionate and flexible Humanitarian and Settlement Programs that meet Australia's international protection obligations and position Australia as a global leader in international resettlement efforts.

Since the end of World War II, Australia has successfully settled more than 950,000 refugees and others in humanitarian need, recognising the valuable contribution that refugees provide to Australian society, culture and prosperity. Australia's Humanitarian Program (the Program) aims to:
meet Australia's international protection obligations, so that Australia is an exemplar in our region and beyond;
provide permanent resettlement to those most in need, who are in desperate situations, including in refugee camps and protracted refugee situations;

use resettlement strategically to help stabilise refugee populations, reduce the prospect of irregular movement from source countries and countries of first asylum, and support broader international protection;
be flexible and responsive to changing global resettlement needs and emerging humanitarian situations to ensure Australia's approach remains comprehensive and high-quality; and
reunite refugees and people who are in refugee-like situations overseas with their family in Australia.

Australia's 2022-23 Humanitarian Program was delivered in full, with 15,875 visas granted in the Offshore program (including the 4,125 additional places allocated to Afghan nationals) and 2,000 visas granted in the Onshore (Protection visa) program.
