A total of 17,875 Humanitarian visas were granted, marking the first time Australia's Humanitarian Program has been fully delivered since 2018-19. 2022-23 also saw the highest number of Community Support Program visa grants since the program's inception in 2018.

A total of 20,000 places in Australia's 2023-24 Humanitarian Program will ensure that we can provide permanent resettlement to those most in need from around the world, and protection in Australia to those who require it. The 2023-24 Humanitarian Program intake is the highest the Program intake has been since 2012-2013.

The world is experiencing the greatest level of humanitarian need in history. The Government is committed to a Humanitarian Program that can respond to international humanitarian crises as they arise.

To ensure Australia continues to play its part, the Government will work closely with both the international and domestic community, particularly the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), as we deliver Australia's humanitarian intake
Consistent with the approach adopted by the UNHCR, Australia will prioritise those cohorts who have the greatest resettlement need. This will focus on:
People outside their home country, assessed as refugees by the UNHCR and referred to Australia for resettlement;
Applicants proposed by a close family member in Australia; and

Vulnerable cohorts within refugee populations, including women and children, ethnic minorities, LGBTIQA+ and other identified minority groups that are referred by the UNHCR or proposed by a close family member in Australia.

While there is no set number of places within the Humanitarian Program for the LGBTIQA+ cohort, they remain a priority in the Program. The Department of Home Affairs records show that 178 humanitarian visas have been granted to persons who identify as LGBTIQA+ since 2019, however data collection on the LGBTIQA+ cohort is reliant on individuals voluntarily informing the Department.

Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. All applications are assessed on an individual basis with applicants required to demonstrate their humanitarian need. Visa grants are subject to rigorous assessment, including health, character and security checks, which are conducted before individuals are granted a visa. Further information on how to apply can be found on the Department's website at: immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/refugee-and-humanitarian-program/about- the-program/resettle-in-australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4863 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Elections
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for referring petition EN4977 about exemptions from compulsory voting and removing fines for individuals who fail to vote. I am responding as Special Minister of State, responsible for electoral matters.

Australia has one of the most accessible, reliable, and transparent electoral systems in the world. The Albanese Government is committed to strengthening the integrity of our electoral system and considers voter confidence in electoral processes imperative to our functioning democracy.

The Labor Party has led legislation for significant federal electoral reform in Australia. Reforms by the Hawke Government in the 1980s provided the framework for Australia's contemporary elections and our democracy. Importantly, that Government transformed our democratic institutions with the creation of the independent Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) to conduct and oversee elections. It also increased transparency in our democratic system by introducing a regime for the regulation and disclosure of political donations and electoral expenditure.

The count process in federal elections is detailed and conducted in a highly transparent manner, with the scrutiny held over a number of weeks. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act} and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 (Referendum Act} contain legislative safeguards to support the integrity of the Australian electoral system, including processes for check and balances on the scrutiny. This involves the AEC conducting an initial sorting of pre-poll votes, scrutiny on voting night and fresh scrutiny. The AEC's operations and procedures, including the Ballot Paper Principles and Ballot Paper Handling Policy, mean that at all times, all ballot papers are tracked, secure and accounted for. More information is available on the AEC's website: www.aec.gov.au.

Protecting the integrity of Australia's electoral processes is critical to maintaining public trust in Australia's democratic processes. The Electoral Integrity Assurance Taskforce (EITA) was established for the 2022 Federal Election to provide information and advice to the Electoral Commissioner on matters that may compromise the real or perceived integrity of the federal election. The EITA is made up of relevant agencies across federal government working together within their own remits. More information on the EITA is available at: https://www.aec.gov.au/about_aec/electoral-integrity.htm.

Additionally, ahead of the 2022 Federal Election, the AEC re-established their 'Stop and Consider Campaign', which builds on the success of a similar campaign run at the 2019 federal election that aims to help voters cut through mis- and disinformation. The AEC also established a disinformation register that lists prominent pieces of disinformation regarding the election process, detailing when the communication was brought to the AEC's attention and actions taken. Similar registers exist at the state and territory level to combat mid and dis information about elections. For example, the NSW Electoral Commission's disinformation register is available at: elections.nsw.gov.au/integrity/disinformation-register.

The petition requests the abolition of compulsory voting. Compulsory voting is the cornerstone of Australian democracy. The Electoral Act and the Referendum Act require all eligible Australian citizens to enrol and vote at each election and referendum. Compulsory voting has been part of Australian federal elections since 1924. The Government supports compulsory voting as it strengthens our democratic process and ensures that the vast majority of citizens actively participate in elections.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
Housing
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5033 on a Royal Commission into the habitual systemic failure of the real estate industry.

Regulation of residential tenancies, including rental agreements and pricing, is a matter for state and territory governments. However, at National Cabinet in August this year the Commonwealth, state and territory governments committed to A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia. This included developing a nationally consistent framework including a requirement for genuine reasonable grounds for eviction, moving towards limiting rental increases to once a year and phasing in minimum rental standards.
These changes will make a tangible impact for the almost one-third of Australian households who rent.

The Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.
This includes the other work being delivered through the National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in new social and affordable homes. This fund will soon receive a further $1 billion to deliver more social homes.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
These measures are in addition to the work that is being delivered.
The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund to support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years has now been legislated by Parliament.
The Government is working with states and territories to deliver the Help to Buy Scheme, supporting up to 40,000 low and middle income households to purchase a home of their own.
We have delivered the largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years is being provided, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rates.
Tax incentives are being introduced to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market.

Federal funding of $1.7 billion has been provided for a one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement with States and Territories, including a $67.5 million boost to homelessness funding over the next year.
Work to deliver on a new National Housing and Homelessness Plan is happening to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

And finally, on 22 June 2023, the Senate referred an inquiry into the worsening rental crisis in Australia to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report, with an interim report to be presented by 23 September 2023 and a final report to be presented by 28 November 2023.
Thank you again for taking the time to share this petition with me. I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Housing
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition ENS044 to introduce a Home Rescue Guarantee scheme.

The Albanese Government recognises the importance of the residential construction sector to the national economy. The residential construction sector is under pressure as it continues to address the effects of the pandemic, supply chain disruptions, labour shortages, rising interest rates and significant price rises for key inputs.

There is a large pipeline of construction work across Australia which means that demand for construction materials and labour remains at elevated levels. However, while house construction input prices continued to rise in the June quarter, this is the fourth consecutive quarter that the pace of growth slowed, as supply chain improvements and falling demand for new construction allow for the backlog of housing to be worked through.

The availability of materials and labour in the construction industry is not expected to ease until around late 2023 to early 2024. Commonwealth, state and territory Building Ministers have noted the significant economic challenges facing the building industry including supply chain, cost and workforce pressures, which have contributed to insolvencies in the sector.

The Government acknowledges the difficult circumstances faced by customers impacted by insolvencies in the residential construction industry, including Porter Davis. Ultimately, regulation of the building industry is a matter for state and territory governments. On 20 April 2023, the Victorian Government announced compensation for customers of Porter Davis who signed their contracts and paid deposits but where Porter Davis did not take out Domestic Building Insurance. The Victorian Government also announced that the Victorian Building Authority is investigating Porter Davis Homes for potential breaches of the law.

On 31 March 2023, Grant Thornton Australia were appointed liquidators of 14 companies in the Porter Davis Homes Group. Any inquiries about the progress of the liquidation or concerns regarding a specific liquidation matter can be raised with the liquidators in the first instance. If this fails to resolve concerns, a complaint may be lodged with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC).

Commonwealth, state and territory senior officials and the Australian Building Codes Board have undertaken work to identify factors constraining the market at the moment, as well as possible opportunities to bolster capacity and alleviate cost pressures. Officials will continue to update this work and report to Commonwealth, state and territory Building Ministers with further work to ensure all possible responses to this critical issue can be considered.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Taxation: Unions
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5058.

The Government provides a range of support to not-for-profit entities through the tax system in recognition of their valuable contribution to Australian society. This includes exempting employment associations, trade unions and other employee associations, and employer associations from income tax. This puts these organisations on the same footing as other not-for-profit entities such as community service organisations, sporting clubs and industry and tourism promotion bodies.

Trade unions and other employee associations are exempt from income tax only if they comply with all the requirements of their governing rules and apply their income and assets solely for the purpose for which they are established. From the 2023-24 tax year, not-for-profit entities (other than registered charities) claiming to be exempt from income tax will need to provide a return to the Australian Taxation Office establishing their eligibility.

It is a longstanding feature of the tax system that periodic subscriptions paid for the membership of a trade, business or professional association (such as union fees) are generally accepted as deductible. Additional membership costs that do not qualify for the general deduction, such as joining fees, may also be deductible up to an annual maximum of $42 for each association.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Fuel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5062 on petrol prices.

The Government recognises that the cost of fuel is putting family and business budgets under significant pressure and driving up the price of essentials like groceries. It remains critical that fuel companies promptly pass on reductions in international oil prices.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is responsible for monitoring fuel prices and plays a critical role in ensuring that market participants do not take advantage of consumers.

As the independent regulator enforcing Australia's competition and consumer laws, the ACCC investigates concerns about misrepresentations regarding fuel prices, and false and misleading conduct or anti- competitive conduct in fuel markets, and takes appropriate action. In addition, the ACCC engages with major retailers and wholesalers to ensure that they do not mislead Australian consumers about the rationale for any price rises. ACCC surveillance has consistently found that local prices tend to follow international prices.

While we understand that petrol price volatility is putting pressure on many Australians, prices have come down significantly since the peak in the middle of 2022. The most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics monthly consumer price index (released 28 June 2023) recorded an average 8 per cent decrease in fuel prices in the year to May 2023. Prices at the end of the 2022-23 financial year had fallen substantially in all capital cities from the 2022 peaks, with the biggest falls seen in Melbourne (of 55.3 cents per litre), Perth (of 48.0 cents per litre), Brisbane (of 46.3 cents per litre) and Sydney (of 44.4 cents per litre).
The Government considers the ACCC best placed to continue monitoring petrol prices. I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Eating Disorders
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding Petition EN5075—eating disorders, more research and resources for anorexia.

I acknowledge the substantial impact eating disorders have on mental, physical, and psychological wellbeing of individuals, as well as on their families and carers. As eating disorders have one of the highest mortality rates of any mental illness, more needs to be done across all sectors to prevent them and improve access to treatment. Access to treatment and supports that is evidence-based is of critical importance to the Australian Government.

To support prevention of eating disorders and promote positive body image, the Government has committed $650,000 to the Butterfly Foundation s Body Bright Program. The Body Bright Program is an education program that promote healthy attitudes and behaviours towards the body, food, and physical exercise in primary school aged children. The Body Bright Program has been well received and continues to build young Australian's capacity to cope with social media exposure.

Through the 2023-24 Budget, the Government announced $6.2 million to support the Embrace Kids Australia program. The Embrace Kids Australia program aims to improve the body image of children and young people and prevent the development of eating disorders. The activities will support schools, sporting clubs, and families to cultivate a body-positive culture.

The Government also continues to support Eating Disorders Families Australia's Strive program, to provide education, learning and peer support to parents, carers, and families of people with eating disorders.

In 2022, the Government provided $13 million to the University of Sydney (InsideOut Institute) to establish the Australian Eating Disorder Research and Translation Centre to progress key eating disorder research priorities related to prevention, early identification, and treatment. This aims to improve outcomes for people with an eating disorder.

A further $63 million has been invested to establish community-based residential eating disorder treatment centres across Australia, including funding for treatment centre at Wandi Nerida on the Sunshine Coast, Queensland.
On 29 May 2023, I announced the outcomes of the $20 million Community-Based Eating Disorder Supports grant opportunity.
The seven initiatives selected to be funded address gaps in the system of care and will deliver specialised services in the community setting:
Eating Disorders Families Australia's 'Fill the Gap' will educate carers on how to be a successful part of the treatment team for their loved one with an eating disorder
Butterfly Foundation's 'Virtual Intensive Outpatient Program' will provide support for people with an eating disorder discharged from hospitals and residential centres
the University of Sydney's eClinic will provide national access to evidence-based digital therapies either by self- or clinician-referral
the National Eating Disorders Collaboration's (NEDC) 'Right Care Right Place' initiative will work with four Primary Health Networks to commission Eating Disorder Care Coordinators in their regions
Eating Disorders Queensland's 'Brief Intervention Therapy for Eating Disorders' will provide evidence-based interventions and supports to provide clients with a guided journey towards recovery
the University of Sydney's 'Digital GP Hub' will support GPs to provide evidence-based eating disorder screening, assessment, treatment and management

headspace National's 'Embedding Eating Disorder Treatment in headspace Centres' will deliver training and support activities to ensure clinicians are able to competently identify and treat someone with an eating disorder and coordinate further care for those requiring more intensive support.
The Government has also committed to the following eating disorder initiatives:
funding the NEDC to help build an effective, equitable and accessible system of care for all Australians
upskilling staff at headspace and Head to Health Centres to provide staff with the education, skills, and tools to help support people suffering from eating disorders, and their families

increasing the accessibility and affordability of eating disorder treatments through dedicated eating disorder items on the Medicare Benefits Schedule, enabling up to 40 psychology and 20 dietetic treatment sessions per year for those eligible
operation of Butterfly Foundation's National Helpline, Eating Disorder Hope, which provides support for those concerned about eating disorders or body image issues and their loved ones.

While the Government has invested significantly in increasing services for eating disorders, state and territory governments are responsible for ensuring access to care in hospital and outpatient settings. We are actively working with state and territory governments and sector stakeholders to further strengthen the whole eating disorder sector.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Taxation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5077 on the Stage 3 tax cuts.
The Government's position on the Stage 3 tax cuts has not changed. Our responsible economic and fiscal management is delivering a stronger and more sustainable fiscal position.

The Government's immediate priority is to focus on dealing with the economic challenges facing us now. Through measures announced in the 2023-24 Budget, the Government is providing cost of living relief that is responsible and affordable and prioritises those most in need: energy bill relief, tripling bulk billing incentives, delivering cheaper medicines, expanded access to Parenting Payment (Single), increased support for people on working age and student payments and more affordable housing.

The Government is improving the budget position in a measured way by strengthening the fairness and sustainability of the tax system. In addition to multinational integrity measures announced in the 2022-23 October Budget, the Government announced in the 2023-24 Budget the implementation of a global and domestic minimum tax rate of 15 per cent for large multinational enterprises. We are also introducing changes to the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax that will mean the offshore LNG industry will pay more tax and sooner. The May Budget also includes better targeting of superannuation concessions by reducing tax concessions available to individuals whose superannuation balance exceeds $3 million. These tax measures will help to ensure a fair and sustainable tax base.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Election of Senators
Dear Chair
Thank you for referring petition EN5087 about the examination of federal elections and preferential voting. I am responding as the Special Minister of State, responsible for electoral matters.

Reforms to Australia's federal electoral system have been led by Labor Governments. In the 1980s the Hawke Government provided the framework for Australia's contemporary elections and democracy. By creating an independent electoral commission to conduct elections, that Government transformed our democratic institutions.
The petition presented here appears to seek that the Senate voting system allow a voter to cast a formal vote by numbering as few candidates on the Senate ballot paper as the voter wishes.

The Senate voting system was an issue examined by the federal parliament's multi-partisan Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSCEM), in its inquiry into the 2013 federal election. Such an inquiry is usual after each general federal election.

A new voting system was recommended by JSCEM at the time and implemented through legislation by the Coalition Government. In 2016, the legislation's swift handling, passage and implementation despite a lack of support from the Labor Opposition, made it controversial.

At that time the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was amended to introduce partial optional preferential voting for the Senate. Under this system, a voter must sequentially number at least 12 candidates below the line on the Senate ballot paper or at least six parties or groups above the line on the Senate ballot paper. Vote-saving provisions mean a vote is not informal if the voter sequentially numbers just six preferences below the line or just one preference above the line.

This amendment also abolished Senate group voting tickets. This means the flow of a voter's preferences now goes only to the parties, groups, or candidates for which the voter explicitly expressed a preference on the ballot paper.

In 2016 the then Government was not concerned with receiving multi-partisan support for electoral change. However, it is my view that significant changes to Australia's federal election laws are best pursued when there is support from across the Parliament. Broad discussion and viewpoints help to improve final legislation and provide greater confidence in effective implementation.

As such, last year I requested JSCEM inquire into the 2022 federal election. I asked JSCEM to consider a range of issues, including proportional representation of the states and territories in the parliament, in the context of the critical democratic principle of 'one vote, one value'. JSCEM's final report is expected this year, with its progress reported at https://www.aph.gov.au/em.

Labor fought for greater fairness and transparency in our electoral system from Opposition, and now from Government we will continue the legacy of reform. As Special Minister of State, I am keenly interested in the outcomes of this JSCEM and moving towards long overdue reforms in our electoral system through broad discussions across the parliament.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Senator Farrell
People with Disability
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 regarding petition EN5097 relating to a request to review the definition of 'person with a disability' in the Copyright Act 1968 (Copyright Act) to ensure it covers 'difficulty physically accessing' copyright material, consistent with Article 3(c) of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works for Persons Who Are Blind, Visually Impaired or Otherwise Print Disabled (Marrakesh Treaty) (which was ratified by Australia on 10 December 2015). I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The Government is committed to Australian copyright law working in a flexible way to encourage equitable access to copyright material by people with a disability in the same way as a person without a disability. The Copyright Act provides for two different copyright exceptions to facilitate the adaptation of copyright materials into an accessible format to assist those with a disability. These are a 'fair dealing' exception for individuals with a disability and any person assisting them (section 113E), and a specific exception for educational institutions and other not-for-profit organisations which have a principal function of assisting persons with a disability in cases where the material cannot be obtained in the required format within a reasonable time at an ordinary commercial price (section 113F).
Under the Copyright Act (subsection 10(1)), a 'person with a disability' is defined as follows:
'person with a disability means a person with a disability that causes the person difficulty in reading, viewing, hearing or comprehending copyright material in a particular form.'

This definition was inserted in 2017 through amendments made by the Copyright Amendment (Disability Access and Other Measures) Act 2017. This Act included a package of measures designed to enhance access to copyright material for persons with a disability, consistent with the Mairnkesh Treaty. As explained in the Explanatory Memorandum that accompanied the Copyright Amendment (Disability Access and Other Measures) Bill 2017 when it was being considered by Parliament:

'This new definition is intended to account for a range of disabilities, consistent with the definition of disability as set out in the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, and to allow flexibility for a wide range of conditions that would impact on an individual's ability to access copyright material. (p. 5)

' ... in practice it would apply to anyone with a disability as defined in the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, where that person's disability causes them difficulty in reading, viewing, hearing or comprehending copyright material.' (p. 13)

While the interpretation of the current definition has not been tested in the Australian courts, it is the Australian Government's view that the definition is broad enough to include a person with any form of disability contemplated by the Mairnkesh Treaty. This would include a person who is 'unable, through physical disability, to hold or manipulate a book or to focus or move the eyes to the extent that would be normally acceptable for reading' (as per Article 3(c) of the Marrakesh Treaty). There appears to be little doubt that this was the intention of the Parliament at the time the Copyright Amendment (Disability Access and Other Measures) Act 2017 was passed.

I am aware that, despite the positive changes to the Copyright Act made in 2017, it may be difficult in practice for Australians with some forms of disability to access a broad range of books in an accessible fo1mat that meets their needs. This may be due to various factors outside of copyright law, such as differing levels of awareness and commercial availability of particular accessible formats, or the resourcing or technical capability of those assisting persons with a disability. I commend the organiser of this petition for her efforts to raise awareness of the importance of making a wide variety of titles accessible to people with physical print disability who use Augmentative and Alternative Communication devices to access books. I also commend those in the publishing industry, education, library and broader not-for-profit sectors who are working to improve the availability of accessible books across various formats so that all Australians can share in the learning and enjoyment that books provide.
I trust this info1mation is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 19 June 2023 regarding petition EN5102 to not ban vaping products, nor to introduce any restrictions that would make it harder to purchase or use vaping products.
The Australian Government is taking clear action to reduce smoking and vaping rates through stronger legislation, enforcement, education and support.

The Government has announced that it will strengthen the regulation and enforcement of both therapeutic and recreational vapes. Subject to further consultation with state and territory governments, a comprehensive range of reforms is proposed including:
stopping the importation of non-prescription vapes
increasing the minimum quality standards for vapes including by restricting flavours colours, and other ingredients
requiring pharmaceutical-like packaging
reducing nicotine concentrations and volumes
banning all single use disposable vapes
ending vape sales in convenience stores and other retail settings (with prescription vapes available through pharmacies).

The Government's announcement follows extensive public consultation led by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) in late 2022 and agreement by all Health Ministers to work together to develop a comprehensive, coordinated suite of reforms to protect Australians from the harms of vaping. More information can be found at https://consultations.tga.gov.au/medicines-regulation-division/proposed-reforms-to-the-regulation-of-nicotine-vap.

The proposed reforms will not ban all vapes. Certain vapes will continue to be available with a doctor s prescription, where clinically appropriate for smoking cessation and the treatment of nicotine addiction. Further details regarding the scope and timeframes for the proposed reforms will be confirmed in consultation with relevant stakeholders, including the states and territories.

The Government's proposed approach aligns with the views of most leading public health organisations in Australia, including the Australian Medical Association, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP), the Cancer Council, and the National Health and Medical Research Council. It also accords with the latest advice on smoking cessation from the RACGP, which states that e-cigarettes should not be a first line treatment for smoking cessation.

While some people may have successfully quit smoking using vapes, the overall evidence of the effectiveness of these products as a smoking cessation aid remains limited. E-cigarettes have been associated with a range of short-term health risks and their long-term health effects are unknown. E-cigarette marketing and use in the community has increased rapidly in recent years, particularly among young people and poses a major risk to population health and Australia's success in tobacco control. Ensuring that e-cigarettes are only accessed with medical supervision provides an opportunity for users to receive appropriate advice from health professionals on the risks associated with their use and the benefits of not smoking.
For people seeking additional support to quit smoking or vaping, a range of support services continue to be available through GPs, Quitline counsellors, pharmacists, and other specialists.

In addition, a range of smoking cessation products approved by the TGA continue to be available, which do not carry the same health risks as vapes. These products have been rigorously assessed by the TGA, have an established safety and efficacy profile and are generally less addictive than vapes. Many are widely available in supermarkets and other retail settings. Products such as nicotine gums, patches and lozenges are also subsidised on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
Further information about these measures is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au by searching 'tackling smoking and vaping'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Research and Development: Animals
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 concerning petition number EN5106, regarding the use of mRNA vaccines in animals.

Australian food safety is rightly one of the most respected in the world. That respect is based on the multi-layer and safety buffers that are applied. Importantly Australia's food safety is not reliant on any one single organisation. Responsibility for regulating the use of vaccines in production animals and food safety in animal products sits across several Australian Government entities.

If mRNA vaccines for production animals are ever successfully developed, these entities will be responsible for determining whether they are safe and can be approved for use within Australia. There is a rigorous scientific process evaluating the safety and efficacy to protect the health and safety of people, animals and the environment.

Before an agricultural or veterinary chemical product, such as a veterinary vaccine, can be legally used in a production animal environment in Australia, it must first be registered by the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA), or approved for use under permit. The APVMA must be satisfied that all proposed agricultural and veterinary chemicals meet the statutory criteria for efficacy, safety (including the risks of residues in food), labelling, and trade prior to registration or approval. The statutory criteria for the use of mRNA vaccines in production animals is subject to the same rigorous process for vaccines produced using existing technology. More information about the role of the APVMA can be found at apvma.gov.au.

In addition, the Gene Technology Regulator has responsibility to protect the health and safety of people and the environment from risks posed by gene technology. As an independent statutory office holder, the Regulator would be involved in aspects of production and use of mRNA vaccines covered by the Gene Technology Act 2000. Further information about the role of the Regulator can be found at: ogtr.gov.au.

Meat, milk and dairy products from livestock that have been vaccinated with an approved Australian vaccine remain safe to eat. These vaccines are used to protect the health and welfare of animals and do not affect the safety of products derived from vaccinated animals. There is no reason to alter consumption of meat, milk and dairy products if mRNA vaccines are used in Australian animals in the future.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me and for the valuable work undertaken by the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt
Sudan
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding petition EN5121 on the conflict and humanitarian crisis in Sudan.

The Australian Government is deeply distressed by the ongoing violence in Sudan which has caused the needless deaths of many hundreds of people and had a profound humanitarian impact. Australia continues to call on all parties to permanently cease hostilities, return to negotiations and enable safe access for humanitarian supplies and workers. We have advocated this position in multilateral fora such as the UN Human Rights Council, as well as with Sudanese authorities and international partners.

We are committed to working with international partners to ease the humanitarian crisis caused by the conflict in Sudan. Australia announced $10.45 million in humanitarian assistance, consisting of $5.45 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross to provide essential humanitarian aid including food, water and emergency medical supplies, as well as $5 million to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to deliver lifesaving assistance across the region.

The Department of Home Affairs continues to process complete applications for temporary, skilled and family visas from Sudanese nationals, as a priority. Applications lodged under the Special Humanitarian Program are prioritised on a case by case basis. On 14 February, more than 19,000 existing Temporary Protection Visa (TPV, Subclass 785) and Safe Haven Enterprise Visa (SHEV, Subclass 790) holders and applicants who had been found to engage

Australia's protection obligations, including Sudanese nationals, became eligible to apply for a permanent Resolution of Status (RoS, Subclass 851) Visa or have their TPV/SHEV application converted to a RoS visa application.

The Australian Government is providing support for the travel and resettlement of refugees, including those from Sudan, through our Humanitarian and Settlement Programs. Any person who believes they meet the requirements of a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australian's assistance can make an application. Each application is considered on its individual merit. Priority is given to the most vulnerable applicants who are assessed as refugees by the UNHCR and formally referred to Australia for resettlement, and those proposed by an immediate family member.

Australia will continue to work with international partners to urge a permanent end to the violence, a return to negotiations and safe access for humanitarian supplies and workers in Sudan. I thank the Petitions Committee for highlighting the traumatic circumstances faced by the people of Sudan due to this conflict.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Grocery Prices
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5128 on the pricing practices of the major supermarkets towards farmers. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government recognises that greater competition is critical for lifting dynamism, productivity and wages growth, putting downward pressure on prices and delivering more choice for Australians dealing with cost-of-living pressures. It has therefore established a Competition Taskforce in Treasury to conduct a review of Australia's competition settings. The review will be progressed over two years, involve targeted public consultation, and provide continuous advice to the Government so progress can be made over time. Initial issues to be considered by the review include mergers reform, aviation and non-compete clauses that restrict workers from shifting to a better-paying job.

Australia's competition laws are contained in the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (CCA), which allows competitive forces within the market to determine prices, while prohibiting anti- competitive conduct by businesses, such as price collusion. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is the agency responsible for enforcing these laws.

There is no direct prohibition on excessive pricing and the Government has a long-standing policy that it does not regulate prices along the supply chain. However, the Government has introduced the Food and Grocery Code of Conduct (the Code) to regulate the commercial dealings between the major supermarkets and their suppliers, including Australian farmers.

The Code imposes obligations on the major supermarkets to improve certainty and transparency in their dealings with suppliers. For example, the supermarkets must engage in price negotiations with suppliers in good faith and take all reasonable steps to conclude negotiations without delay.

Under the Code, suppliers have access to Code Arbiters, who must take reasonable steps to investigate and resolve complaints. If a supplier is dissatisfied with the process undertaken by the Code Arbiter, they may request that the Independent Reviewer, Mr Chris Leptos AO, review the Code Arbiter's process in dealing with the complaint. Further information on the dispute resolution process is available on the Independent Reviewer's website at www.grocerycodereviewer.gov.au.

The Code also aims to promote and support good faith commercial dealings between supermarkets, wholesalers and suppliers. The Government is undertaking a review of the Code, which will include public consultations, to ensure that the law remains effective.
Interested parties will have the opportunity to make a submission to this review process. Further information on the review as it progresses can be found at www.treasury.gov.au/consultation.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury, Dr Leigh
Disability Support Pension
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 1 August 2023, concerning petition no. EN5131 regarding the income test for Disability Support Pension (DSP) recipients. I hope the below information on DSP income test settings addresses the points raised in the petition.
The DSP income test is designed to encourage people to supplement their income support payments with other income, if they are able to and wish to do so.

A DSP recipient and their partner can receive an amount of income before their payment starts to be reduced. This amount may comprise income from investments, earnings, or a combination of income from various sources and is known as the income free area. From 1 July 2023, the DSP income free area is $204 a fortnight for singles and $360 a fortnight for couples combined. The DSP income free area is adjusted each year in July for increases in the cost of living using the Consumer Price Index.

As noted in the petition, for each dollar of income over the income free area the single rate of DSP is reduced by 50 cents (the taper rate). For couples, each of their individual payments is reduced by 25 cents a fortnight for each dollar of income that the couple has over the income free area. This means that from 1 July 2023, a part rate of DSP is payable up to an assessable income of $2,332.00 a fortnight for a single person or $3,568.00 a fortnight for a couple. These figures may be higher if Rent Assistance is paid with the pension.

Working age payment recipients (such as DSP recipients who are under Age Pension age) are further incentivised to take up paid work where they can through the Working Credit arrangements. Recipients who have built up a Working Credit balance are able to use it to reduce the value of their earnings counted under the income test.

The operation of the DSP income free area, taper rate and Working Credit means that DSP recipients are better off while they (or their partner) are earning income in addition to their income support payments.

DSP recipients who have high earnings from employment or inform Services Australia they are starting work of 30 hours or more a week are able to have their DSP suspended for up to 2 years. This means if the person is unable to cope with the job, or needs to reduce their hours of work because of their disability, they can return to DSP without having to make a new claim.

Under the Social Services and Other Legislation Amendment (Workforce Incentive) Act 2022, from 1 January 2023, DSP recipients suspended due to work are also able to retain access to their Pensioner Concession Card and associated benefits for 2 years.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth
Ukraine
Dear Chair
Thank you for the petition presented to the House of Representatives regarding military assistance to Ukraine. I appreciate the concerns raised by Mr Daugherty on these matters.

The Australian Government has repeatedly condemned Russia's unprovoked and illegal invasion of Ukraine and continues to call for its withdrawal from Ukrainian territory. The Government is providing military assistance to Ukraine to support its defence.

Australia's military assistance to Ukraine now totals approximately $710 million. Australia's assistance package includes over 200 vehicles, artillery, ammunition and training for Ukrainian military recruits. Australia will also deploy an E-7A Wedgetail aircraft to help protect a vital gateway of humanitarian assistance to Ukraine.

The international community is focussing on providing Ukraine only one fighter aircraft platform, namely the F-16. In addition to requiring Ukrainian training on a second aircraft, the F/A-18 Hornets are at an advanced stage of the disposal process and it is not feasible to return the aircraft to an operational state. The Government continues to consider options for further military assistance to Ukraine.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles (Petition No. EN5142)
Endometriosis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding Petition EN5155 seeking to list Visanne(r) (dienogest) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for endometriosis.

The Australian Government is addressing endometriosis and pelvic pain, including specific clinics in general practice and improved access to medicines listed on the PBS and to medical services available via Medicare involved in the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis.

One initiative involved a review of Medicare Benefits Schedule and PBS items used to support the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis to be undertaken. The review will report on available treatments for endometriosis and pelvic pain and recommendations for both improved utilisation of items and promotion of available treatments.

The Government is committed to ensuring Australians have access to affordable medicines by listing medicines recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) on the PBS. The PBAC is an independent, expert body comprising doctors, health professionals, health economists and consumer representatives. Its primary role is to advise me, as the Minister for Health and Aged Care, about medicines and medicinal preparations that should be funded on the PBS. Under legislation, the Government cannot list a new medicine on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of its listing.

When considering a medicine proposed for PBS listing, the PBAC is legally required to consider the comparative effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the medicine compared to other available therapies. The PBAC's consideration is generally initiated by the pharmaceutical company responsible for supply of the medicine, as the pharmaceutical company usually holds the scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.

A stocktake of medicines listed on the PBS for the treatment of endometriosis and related conditions was considered by the PBAC in December 2022, to identify potential gaps between medicines subsidised through the PBS and medicines available to patients privately (at full cost). The PBAC noted that dienogest is Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) registered for endometriosis and its use is supported by clinical guidelines but is not PBS-subsidised.

The PBAC identified barriers to improving access to medicines used in the treatment of endometriosis, including the willingness of pharmaceutical companies to pursue a TGA registration and subsequent PBS listing for endometriosis. Further information about the PBAC's consideration and outcome is available at www.pbs.gov.au/info/industry/listing/elements/pbac-meetings/pbac-outcomes/recommendations-made-by-the-pbac-december-2022-intracycle.

Currently, there are four brands of dienogest that are TGA-registered for use in Australia. The pharmaceutical company responsible for Visanne is Bayer Australia Ltd (Bayer), and the pharmaceutical company responsible for the other brands is Arrotex Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd (Arrotex).

Earlier this year, the Department of Health and Aged Care wrote to Bayer and Arrotex to seek an expression of interest in applying for the PBS listing of these products for the treatment of endometriosis. To date, the PBAC has not received a submission requesting the PBS listing of dienogest. You may wish to contact Bayer and Arrotex to find out if they intend to make a submission to the PBAC to list dienogest on the PBS for the treatment of endometriosis. Bayer can be contacted by phone on 1800 008 757 and Arrotex can be contacted on 1300 927 769.

Pharmaceutical companies are private businesses that makes their own decisions about the pricing of their medicines and whether they will market them exclusively on the private market or apply for subsidy through the PBS. The Government cannot compel pharmaceutical companies to seek PBS subsidies for their medicines.

Where a medicine is not listed on the PBS, private health insurers are free to pay benefits, under general treatment cover, for the full price of the medicine. Health insurers may choose to offer this cover as a value-added feature of their policies, subject to any terms and conditions they choose to set. This is a commercial decision for the health insurer.

All aspects of patient care, including recommendations about appropriate treatments, are the responsibility of the treating doctor. Individuals may wish to discuss with their treating doctor whether there are suitable treatment alternatives available for the treatment of their condition under the PBS.

The Government has also established a National Women's Health Advisory Council (Council) to provide strategic advice and recommendations directly to Government to improve health outcomes for Australian women and girls. The Council will also provide advice on the implementation of the National Women's Health Strategy 2020-2030, which outlines a national approach to reducing inequalities and improving health outcomes for all women and girls particularly those at greatest risk of poor health.

On 25 May 2023, the Senate Community Affairs Committee tabled its report on universal access to reproductive healthcare 'Ending the postcode lottery: addressing barriers to sexual, maternity and reproductive healthcare in Australia'. The Government is considering the recommendations in the report, which includes ensuring access to sexual and reproductive health medicines on the PBS and will respond in due course.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Wagner Group
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 enclosing Petition EN5157, with 17 signatures, concerning the potential listing of the Wagner Group as a terrorist organisation and the maintenance of autonomous sanctions on the Wagner Group.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned about the Wagner Group's operations and continues to closely monitor its involvement in Russia's war in Ukraine and beyond. Australia imposed targeted financial sanctions on the Wagner Group on 18 May 2022.

For an organisation to be listed as a terrorist organisation, it must satisfy the legislative criteria set out in Division 102 of the Criminal Code, namely that the organisation must be either directly or indirectly involved in preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, or advocates the doing of a terrorist act.

As you will appreciate, consideration of these matters are sensitive and complex. It is the Government's longstanding practice not to comment on whether an organisation is being, or has been, considered for listing.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5157 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Workplace Relations
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding petition number EN5159, which proposes a platform for remote overseas employees to raise employment issues.
The Fair Work Act 2009 (Fair Work Act) provides the framework for workplace relations in Australia. It also applies beyond Australia to Australian employers and employees.

Whether an employee working overseas for an Australian employer is classified as Australian-based or not depends on the individual circumstances, including where the employment contract was formed and whether they are engaged to perform duties outside Australia. An employee engaged outside Australia to perform duties outside Australia is generally not an Australian-based employee. Generally, Australian-based employees working overseas have entitlements under the national workplace relations system while non- Australian-based employees working overseas may be covered by the entitlements under the laws of the countries where they work.

Where the Fair Work Act applies, the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO) provides education, assistance and advice about Australian workplace laws, and, where appropriate, impartially enforces those laws. Contact details for the FWO, including a phone number for calling from outside Australia, can be found at www.fairwork.gov.au/about-us/contact-us.
Thank you for writing to me seeking consideration of this issue and petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Medicare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN5169, which requests the Australian Government implement the 2007 Parliamentary Inquiry into Breastfeeding. Specifically, that International Board-Certified Lactation Consultants (IBCLC) should be granted access to the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) as allied health professionals.

The Australian Government recognises the significant health benefits of breast feeding for both women and their babies and appreciates the expertise of skilled health professionals when assisting women to achieve their breastfeeding goals.

The Australian National Breastfeeding Strategy: 2019 and beyond (Strategy) builds on the work of previous breastfeeding strategies to increase rates of breastfeeding in Australia. The Strategy provides a framework for integrated, coordinated action to provide supportive and enabling environments for breastfeeding. It identifies individual, community and structural enablers to support mothers and protect and promote breastfeeding.

Since 2010, the MBS has supported participating midwives to provide quality care to patients by subsidising a range of private maternity services, including antenatal, intrapartum, and postnatal care. Postnatal attendances may include services relating to breastfeeding and there are IBCLC qualified midwives who provide this service as part of the postnatal attendance items.

The planning and delivery of public maternity services is predominantly undertaken by states and territories with the Australian Government providing national direction and supporting efforts to improve care and outcomes. Under the National Health Reform Agreement, the Australian Government provides a significant funding contribution to assist states and territories with the costs of public hospital and community health services, including maternity services.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Honours and Awards

p.span: Australian Defence Force: Honours and Awards
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 concerning Petition EN5170—Review of awards to commanders of Joint Task Force 633. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Afghanistan Inquiry Report (the Report} is a hugely significant document, and given the appalling nature of the allegations which are contained within it, the Albanese Government is committed to implementing recommendations of the report to the fullest possible extent.

The Report recommended that the award of decorations to those in command positions at troop, squadron and task group level during a number of Special Operations Task Group rotations be reviewed. The Chief of the Defence Force has conducted a review and the matter is now subject to my consideration.

Reviewing the awarded decorations of those who served our nation is not a responsibility undertaken lightly. As the process is ongoing, and to protect the privacy and support the welfare of all involved, it would not be appropriate to comment further.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Tarkine
Dear Chair
Thank you for your referred petition of 31 July 2023 about placing the Tarkine Rainforest as a no go area for commercial and industrial agreements (Petition Number EN5171).

The Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conversation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) is Australia's key legislation that helps protect our environment. Under the EPBC Act, a rigorous assessment is undertaken of the potential impacts of projects on matters of national environmental significance that are listed under the Act.

I appreciate the concerns reflected in the petition regarding the proposed MMG activity and its potential impact on the Tarkine region. MMG's proposed new tailings dam is being assessed under the EPBC Act Bilateral Agreement between the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian Government. MMG has prepared an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), which is required to include an analysis of alternatives for tailings disposal, including alternative dam locations, technologies and management practices, and their associated environmental impacts.

The EIS has now been published for a period of public consultation. I encourage all interested parties to make a submission to this process. The link is available here: Comment· EPBC Act Public Portal (awe.gov.au}.
Following completion of the assessment, the Tasmanian Government will provide an assessment report and a decision will be made by the Commonwealth on whether or not to approve the proposal.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Honours and Awards

p.span: Australian Defence Force: Honours and Awards
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding Petition EN5l79—Review of Afghanistan Awards. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Afghanistan Inquiry Report (the Report) is a hugely significant document, and given the appalling nature of the allegations which are contained within it, the Albanese Government is committed to implementing recommendations of the report to the fullest possible extent.

The Report recommended that the award of decorations to those in command positions at troop, squadron and task group level during a number of Special Operations Task Group rotations be reviewed. The Chief of the Defence Force has conducted a review and the matter is now subject to my consideration.
Reviewing the awarded decorations of those who served our nation is not a responsibility undertaken lightly. As part of my ongoing considerations on this matter I am able to seek independent advice.
As my considerations are ongoing, and to protect the privacy and support the welfare of all involved, it would not be appropriate to comment further.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Wagner Group
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 enclosing Petition EN5196, with 1108 signatures, concerning the potential listing of the Wagner Group as a terrorist organisation and the maintenance of autonomous sanctions on the Wagner Group.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned about the Wagner Group's operations and continues to closely monitor its involvement in Russia's war in Ukraine and beyond. Australia imposed targeted financial sanctions on the Wagner Group on 18 May 2022.

For an organisation to be listed as a terrorist organisation, it must satisfy the legislative criteria set out in Division 102 of the Criminal Code, namely that the organisation must be either directly or indirectly involved in preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, or advocates the doing of a terrorist act.

As you will appreciate, consideration of these matters are sensitive and complex. It is the Government's longstanding practice not to comment on whether an organisation is being, or has been, considered for listing.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5196 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for petition EN5211 dated 1 August 2023, concerning child support.

The Australian Government is aware of the difficulties that are faced by parents who experience family breakdown, including the stress of disputes in relation to child support. The Government intends the Child Support scheme be fair to ensure children are financially supported by both parents.

The petition suggests parents should only be entitled to receive child support if they are working full time (where possible). The Government appreciates that parents face difficult choices in balancing their desire to care for their children with the need to work to improve their family's financial situation. Families have a diversity of parenting arrangements and responsibilities and the Government supports these choices as far as possible. However, the Government understands that for child support purposes, the work decisions one parent makes can affect how much child support the other parent may pay or receive.

The policy settings for social security and family assistance payments support the Government's broader workforce participation agenda as well as supporting the policy position that parents should be encouraged to enter the workforce, or increase their hours of work as their children get older.

In relation to child support, although the Government cannot force parents to make certain decisions about their lifestyle or employment, if either parent believes their child support assessment is unfair because of the special circumstances of their case, they can seek a review under the change of assessment process.

Services Australia can change an assessment based on a parent's earning capacity if the parent is not working despite ample opportunity to do so, or has changed their hours of work, and their decision is not justified by either their caring responsibilities or state of health.

The petitioners also raise concerns about parental alienation, and that parents should not receive child support if the children do not have equal access to both parents. While the Government encourages involvement of both parents in their children's lives, the Child Support scheme does not play any role in establishing or enforcing care arrangements for children. Services Australia does not have the authority to compel parents to adhere to previously agreed, or negotiate with parents regarding, care arrangements. These issues are best dealt with through mediation or dispute resolution, or pursued through the family law system. The ongoing day-to-day financial support of children is the key objective of the Child Support scheme, and it is important that child support is not limited or withheld until access arrangements can be agreed.

As the petitioners may be aware, the Family Relationship Advice Line (1800 050 321) is a free, national telephone service which provides assistance with family separation issues, as well as referrals to other services that can help parents strengthen relationships, overcome differences and assist with their specific needs. More information about Family Relationship Centres can be found at www.familyrelationships.gov.au.

The Government shares concerns about 'undeclared cash' due to non-reporting or under-reporting of income for tax and other purposes. From 1 July 2019, the Government removed tax deductions to employers and payers of certain contractor payments, including cash wages where reporting obligations have not been met. The Government also established a tip-off line to report phoenixing, tax evasion and black economy activity and help keep the system fair for everyone. For more information about the Government's continuing work on the black economy, visit www.treasury.gov.au/policy-topics/economy/black-economy.

For child support purposes, a parent's taxable income is used to assess how much child support a parent pays or receives. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is responsible for determining and verifying taxable income. If a source of income is assessed as taxable by the ATO, it is used by Services Australia to calculate child support assessments.

However, while a formula assessment reflects the needs of most separated families, sometimes the realities of a case mean the formula does not adequately address the circumstances of both parents and their children. If a parent believes that their former partner's taxable income is not an accurate reflection of their financial capacity, they may wish to discuss the option to apply for a change of assessment with Services Australia.

The petition also raises 2 further areas of concern—the treatment of children from new relationships, and the costs of supporting step-children. When a parent is responsible for supporting a new biological or adopted child, the Child Support scheme recognises this financial responsibility through the 'relevant dependent child amount'.

The 'relevant dependent child amount' reduces a parent's child support income, which can result in a change to the child support assessment, and ensures the parent has financial capacity to support all their children.

Where one parent's income decreases, it will reduce the cost of the children in the assessment and result in a change in each parent's income percentage. If the paying parent's income decreases due to the relevant dependent child amount, this may result in less child support being payable.

If the receiving parent's income decreases due to the relevant dependent child amount, this may result in a higher rate of child support being payable. However, this will be offset by the assessment having a lower child support liability overall due to lower combined child support income.

The Child Support scheme is based on the principle that it is the biological or adoptive parents' responsibility to support their own children. For this reason, step-children are not automatically taken into account in the child support formula. Parents do not have a legal duty to support a step-child without a court order imposing such a duty. A parent can apply for a change of assessment in very limited circumstances to request that the financial support of a step-child is recognised as part of their child support assessment. For example, a parent would need to demonstrate that the step-child's own parents cannot financially support them for reasons such as ill-health or other caring responsibilities.

The petitioners may be interested to know that in the 2023-24 Budget, the Government committed $5.1 million to implement key child support recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Australia's Family Law System (committee). The key interests of the committee were to ensure the Child Support scheme balances the interests of separated parents, reflects current community standards and, importantly, continues supporting the best interests of children. The committee's report and the Government's response (tabled on 25 January 2023) are available at
.www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Family_Law_System.
As part of the response to the committee's report, the Government agreed to a range of recommendations to improve the Child Support Scheme over the longer term, including the following:

The Government has established a Child Support Stakeholder Consultation Group who will perform a key advisory role for government on a range of policy and service delivery issues that impact the efficient operation of the Scheme, and positive outcomes for separated parents.

In response to Recommendations 14, 18 and 19 of the Committee's Third Interim Report, the Government has agreed to establish a Child Support Expert Panel, and commission research into the costs of raising children in Australia. The Expert Panel will review the costs of children findings to make recommendations on whether and how to update the Costs of the Children Table (and formula).
The Government continues to monitor the effect of child support legislation and service delivery. Feedback and recommendations from the community are important to this process.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Social Services, Ms Rishworth

subdebateinfo.title: Embassy of the Russian Federation in Australia

p.span: Embassy of the Russian Federation in Australia
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 enclosing Petition EN5219, with 1080 signatures, concerning the Home Affairs Act 2023.

The Home Affairs Act 2023 terminated a lease held by the Government of the Russian Federation on a block of land adjacent to Parliament House. The termination of the lease was necessary to protect Australia's national security interests, and is consistent with Australia's international and domestic legal obligations. It does not preclude the Government of the Russian Federation from maintaining a diplomatic presence in Canberra, which they do at their premises in Griffith.
The Australian Government will always act in Australia's national interests. Thank you for bringing Petition EN5219 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neil
Breast Cancer
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding petition number EN5221 requesting free mammogram and ultrasound services for the early detection of breast cancer in woman and men aged 18 to 49 years.

The Australian Government is committed to reducing the impact of breast cancer on all Australians and provides funding and support through the BreastScreen Australia (BreastScreen) program and Medicare.

BreastScreen aims to reduce morbidity and mortality from breast cancer by actively inviting women in the target age group ofS0-74 years to attend free two-yearly screening mammograms. This is known to be most effective in diagnosing and assessing breast cancer in this age group. This target age range is also consistent with advice from the International Agency for Research on Cancer. Women aged 40-49 years and 75 years and older are also eligible to participate in the BreastScreen program but do not receive an invitation to attend. Further information on the BreastScreen program including is current projects and activities is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website www.health.gov.au by using the search term 'BreastScreen Australia'.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare publishes an annual report on the BreastScreen program, which can be accessed on their website at www.aihw.gov.au by using the search term 'BreastScreen'.

Age is the greatest breast cancer risk and younger women are less likely to develop breast cancer. Mammography is less effective at detecting breast cancer in younger women because both breast cancer and dense breast tissue appear as white areas on mammograms. For men, the harms of screening mammograms are currently assessed as outweighing any potential benefits. These risks include undergoing unnecessary procedures, discomfort during screening, and exposure to radiation. As a result, men are not currently targeted in the BreastScreen program.

According to data from Cancer Australia, male breast cancer accounts for 1% of all breast cancers. The data indicates that an estimated 20,640 Australians. were diagnosed with breast cancer in 2022 (20,428 females and 212 males). Cancer Australia also have information for men with breast cancer available on their website at www.breastcancerinmen.canceraustralia.gov.au.

According to data from Cancer Australia, male breast cancer accounts for 1% of all breast cancers. The data indicates that an estimated 20,640 Australians were diagnosed with breast cancer in 2022 {20,428 females and 212 males). Cancer Australia also have information for men with breast cancer available on their website at www.breastcancerinmen.canceraustralia.gov.au.

Regarding making breast diagnosis services free under Medicare, doctors are free to set their own prices, and the actual fee charged is a matter between the doctor and the patient. When determining their fees, doctors are encouraged to consider the personal circumstances of their patients, and many do so.

The Government recognises breast imaging is an important tool in the investigation of breast changes. In general, services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule are for diagnostic purposes and are not for screening purposes. Patient rebates are provided through Medicare for tests such as mammograms, ultrasounds, and imaging guided biopsies for patients of any age and gender with symptoms of breast cancer or a significant family history. Medicare rebates are also available for a small number of specific breast magnetic resonance imaging scans based on clinical evidence. In 2022-23, Medicare expenditure on breast imaging services totalled $198.6 million.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Age Pension
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 11 September 2023 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning Petition EN5224 relating to the Age Pension age. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring the Age Pension is sustainable and future demand can be met. The Government expects to spend around $59 billion on the Age Pension in 2023-24 to assist around 2.6 million eligible Australians.

A person must meet both eligibility and payability criteria in order to receive the Age Pension. To be eligible, a person must be of Age Pension age (67 years) and satisfy the residence requirements. To be payable, a person must also have income and assets below certain limits.

The petition suggests changing the Age Pension age to 65. When the Age Pension was introduced in 1909, the average male life expectancy at birth was 55. It is now over 80. Consistent with legislation passed in 2009, the Age Pension age gradually increased from 65 years to 67 years between 2017 and 2023. The Government believes that the increase in the Age Pension age to 67 is appropriate. It does not have any plans to increase the Age Pension age any further.

If a person below Age Pension qualification age requires income support, they may be eligible for an alternative social security payment. For example, they may qualify for payments such as JobSeeker Payment or the Disability Support Pension, subject to eligibility criteria.

When people reach 60 years of age, they may also become eligible for extra concessions from state and local government authorities through the Seniors Card. Recipients aged 60 or over are able to access their superannuation tax-free if they are paid from a taxed superannuation fund, which is another concession that benefits many seniors.
The Minister appreciates you bringing this matter to her attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Mrs Elliot
Disability Support Pension
Dear Chair
Thank you for the notice of a petition referral (petition number EN5235) dated 11 September 2023 regarding increasing the rate of the Disability Support Pension (DSP).

Australia's social security system is designed to provide a safety net for people who, for reasons such as age, disability, caring responsibilities or unemployment, are unable to fully support themselves. The Government is committed to a system that supports the most vulnerable, encourages those who are able to work or study, and is sustainable for future generations.

Pensions, including DSP, are paid at the highest legislated rate of income support payments in the social security system. Base pensions are indexed twice a year, in March and September, to the higher of the increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and the increase in the Pensioner and Beneficiary Living Cost Index (PBLCI). The CPI and PBLCI measure changes in prices on a range of goods and services such as food, health care, telecommunications, fuel, housing and utilities costs. Base pension rates are also benchmarked to Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE) to align them with community living standards.

The last indexation occurred on 20 September 2023. The maximum total pension rate for single pensioners increased by $32.70 to $1,096.70 a fortnight.
